paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (4) of this subsection, the County Commissioners of Dorchester County shall pay at least the sum of $118,500 each year to the volunteer fire companies in the county for their benefit as long as the volunteer fire companies are active, fire-fighting organizations.
Each volunteer fire company shall use the money received to support, maintain, equip, and operate the volunteer fire company for the purpose of fighting fires in the county.
Each volunteer fire company shall comply with the bylaws of the Volunteer Fire Companies Association of Dorchester County.

The County Commissioners may not make a payment to a volunteer fire company unless the volunteer fire company complies with the bylaws of the Volunteer Fire Companies Association of Dorchester County.

subsection.text: The County Commissioners shall use property tax revenue to pay volunteer fire companies in accordance with subsection (b) of this section.

paragraph.text: The County Commissioners shall distribute the money required by subsection (b) of this section on October 1 of each year to the following volunteer fire companies in at least the following amounts:
The Elliotts Volunteer Fire Company shall receive an amount set by the County Commissioners.

Before paying money to a volunteer fire company, the County Commissioners may require the officers of the volunteer fire company to appear before the County Commissioners and submit evidence satisfactory to the County Commissioners that the volunteer fire company:

subparagraph.text: is an active fire-fighting organization; and
has spent the money received in prior years under this section in accordance with this section.

paragraph.text: If a volunteer fire company ceases to be an active fire-fighting organization or fails to spend the money received in accordance with this section, the County Commissioners shall:

subparagraph.text: withhold the current year’s money from the volunteer fire company; and
allocate the unspent money to the contingent fund of Dorchester County.

subsection.text: This section applies to Allegany County, Calvert County, Charles County, Frederick County, Garrett County, Kent County, and St. Mary’s County.
The county commissioners of a county subject to this section have the express power to guarantee or insure financial loans made by a governmental third party to a volunteer fire company that:

paragraph.text: is located within the county; or
has a mutual aid agreement with the county.
Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, this subtitle applies in Baltimore City.
In Baltimore City, the Baltimore City fire department shall enforce this subtitle.
In Baltimore City, appeals concerning this subtitle shall be made to the Baltimore City fire board.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not affect a public local law or regulation that existed on July 1, 1982, that required smoke detectors in occupancies with less than ten dwelling units.

paragraph.text: Each sleeping area within each occupancy classified residential, as defined in the most recent edition of the National Fire Protection Association Life Safety Code adopted by the State Fire Prevention Commission, shall be equipped with at least one approved smoke detector that:

subparagraph.text: senses visible or invisible particles of combustion; and
is installed in a manner and location approved by the State Fire Prevention Commission.

paragraph.text: When activated, the smoke detector shall provide an alarm suitable to warn the occupants.
The landlord shall install smoke detectors as required under subsection (a) of this section.
On written notification by certified mail by the tenant or on notification in person by the tenant, the landlord shall repair or replace the smoke detector.
If the tenant personally notifies the landlord of the failure of a smoke detector, the landlord shall provide a written receipt acknowledging the notification.
A tenant may not remove a smoke detector or render a smoke detector inoperative.
Except for hotels or motels, a landlord may require a refundable deposit for a smoke detector not exceeding the value of the smoke detector.
On written request of a tenant who is deaf or hearing impaired, the landlord shall provide a smoke detector that, when activated, provides a signal that:

subparagraph.text: is approved by a nationally recognized testing laboratory for electrical appliances; and
is sufficient to warn the deaf or hearing impaired tenant.

paragraph.text: Regardless of the number of units, each hotel or motel shall have available at least one smoke detector for the deaf or hearing impaired for each 50 units or fraction of 50 units.
The hotel or motel may require a refundable deposit for a portable smoke detector not exceeding the value of the smoke detector.
The hotel or motel shall post in a conspicuous place at the registration desk a permanent sign that states the availability of smoke detectors for the deaf or hearing impaired.

subsection.text: On or before July 1, 1982, an occupant of a one, two, or three family residential dwelling constructed before July 1, 1975, shall:

paragraph.text: equip each occupant’s living unit with at least one approved battery or alternating current (AC) primary electric powered smoke detector; and
maintain the smoke detector.

subsection.text: At least one smoke detector shall be installed on each level, including a basement but excluding an attic, of each new residential dwelling unit:

paragraph.text: that contains alternating current (AC) electrical service;
that is classified residential, as defined in the most recent edition of the National Fire Protection Association Life Safety Code adopted by the State Fire Prevention Commission; and
for which a building permit is issued for new construction on or after January 1, 1989.

subsection.text: If two or more smoke detectors are required under subsection (a) of this section, the smoke detectors shall be of a type and installed in a manner so that activation of one smoke detector causes activation of all other required smoke detectors in the residential dwelling unit.

A smoke detector required under this subtitle shall operate both by battery and on an alternating current (AC) primary source of electric power if the smoke detector is installed in a new residential dwelling unit:

paragraph.text: that contains alternating current (AC) electrical service;
that is designed to be occupied by one or more families; and
for which a building permit is issued for new construction on or after July 1, 1990.

subsection.text: This section:

paragraph.text: may be enforced by a county fire chief, fire administrator, or municipal fire chief; and
does not prevent a county from enacting more stringent laws that relate to smoke detectors.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection and § 9-102(d) of this subtitle, smoke detection systems shall operate on an alternating current (AC) primary source of electric power.
Smoke detection systems may operate on approved power supplies other than an alternating current (AC) primary source of electric power if:

subparagraph.text: the power supply is approved by the State Fire Prevention Commission; and
it is clearly evident that reasonable safety is secured.

subsection.text: Each approved smoke detector shall be installed so as not to exceed the lineal or square footage allowances specified for the smoke detector, based on the generally accepted test standards under which the smoke detector was tested and approved.

Smoke detection systems, including specialized smoke detectors for the deaf and hearing impaired, shall be approved for the particular system and shall only be used for detection and signaling in the event of fire.
Each lease for an existing residential dwelling unit that contains alternating current (AC) electric service shall contain a disclosure in 10-point bold type that states:

“This residential dwelling unit contains alternating current (AC) electric service. In the event of a power outage, an alternating current (AC) powered smoke detector will not provide an alarm. Therefore, the occupant should obtain a dual powered smoke detector or a battery powered smoke detector.”

section.text: A person may sell or install a smoke detection system, smoke detector, smoke alarm, or specialized smoke detectors or smoke alarms for the deaf and hard of hearing only in accordance with the State Fire Prevention Code.

subsection.text: If approved by the State Fire Prevention Commission, an approved automatic fire sprinkler system may be installed instead of a smoke detection system.

Installing an approved automatic fire sprinkler system does not nullify the other requirements of the State Fire Prevention Code or exempt an occupancy from other requirements that are clearly applicable under the State Fire Prevention Code.

section.text: Failure to comply with this subtitle may not be used as a policy defense in the settlement of a property insurance claim.

subsection.text: If after investigating a fire in a one, two, or three family residential dwelling the State Fire Marshal or local investigating authority finds the absence of required smoke detectors, the State Fire Marshal or local investigating authority shall issue to the occupant a smoke detection installation order.
A person may not fail to comply with a smoke detection installation order within 15 days of reoccupancy.

paragraph.text: A person who violates subsection (b) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $50.
The penalty provision of § 9-109 of this subtitle does not apply to this section.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly violate this subtitle.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 10 days or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Dormitory” means a building or space in a building that:

subparagraph.text: is under joint occupancy and single management; and
provides group sleeping accommodations:

sub-subparagraph.text: with or without meals, but without individual cooking facilities;
for more than 16 individuals who are not members of the same family group; and
in one room or in a series of closely associated rooms.

paragraph.text: “Dormitory” includes a school dormitory, fraternity house, and military barracks.

subsection.text: “Dwelling unit” means a single unit that:

paragraph.text: provides complete, independent living facilities for one or more individuals; and
contains permanent provisions for living, sleeping, eating, cooking, and sanitation.
“Hotel” means a building or group of buildings that:

subparagraph.text: is under the same management;
contains more than 16 sleeping accommodations for hire; and
is used primarily by transients who are lodged with or without meals.

paragraph.text: “Hotel” includes an inn, motel, club, and apartment hotel.
“Lodging or rooming house” means a building:

subparagraph.text: in which separate sleeping rooms are rented; and
that provides sleeping accommodations:

sub-subparagraph.text: for 16 or fewer individuals;
on either a transient or permanent basis; and
with or without meals, but without individual cooking facilities.

paragraph.text: “Lodging or rooming house” includes an inn, club, and bed and breakfast establishment.
“Multifamily residential dwelling” means a building or part of a building that:

subparagraph.text: contains more than two dwelling units; and
is not classified as a one or two family dwelling.

paragraph.text: “Multifamily residential dwelling” does not include a town house.
“Public water system” means a system that:

subparagraph.text: provides the public with piped water for human consumption; and
has at least 15 service connections or regularly serves at least 25 individuals.

paragraph.text: “Public water system” includes:

subparagraph.text: a collection, treatment, storage, or distribution facility that is under the control of the operator of the system and is used primarily in connection with the system; and
a collection or pretreatment storage facility that is not under the control of the operator of the system and is used primarily in connection with the system.

subsection.text: “Sprinkler system” means a device that:

paragraph.text: opens automatically by operation of a heat responsive releasing mechanism;
discharges water in a specific pattern over a designated area to extinguish or control fire; and
uses the same service water supply pipe to the dwelling unit that the public water system uses.

subsection.text: “Town house” means a single family dwelling unit that is constructed in a horizontal series of attached units with property lines separating the units.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, this subtitle does not preclude a local jurisdiction from adopting more stringent standards to govern the installation of sprinkler systems in new construction.

Industrialized buildings under the authority of the Department of Housing and Community Development in accordance with Title 12, Subtitle 3 of this article shall comply with the standard for the installation of sprinkler systems in residential occupancies as adopted in the regulations of the State Fire Prevention Commission.

section.text: The State Fire Marshal or a local or State authority with jurisdiction over the enforcement of fire and building codes may enforce this subtitle.

subsection.text: Each sprinkler system required under this section shall:

paragraph.text: be installed in accordance with accepted engineering practices that meet the standard for the installation of sprinkler systems in residential occupancies under the regulations of the State Fire Prevention Commission or the local authority with jurisdiction over the enforcement of fire and building codes;
meet the requirements of the current National Fire Protection Association standards; and
be approved by the State Fire Marshal or the local authority with jurisdiction over the enforcement of fire codes.
In a jurisdiction in which building permits are issued, a sprinkler system shall be installed in:

subparagraph.text: each newly constructed dormitory, hotel, lodging or rooming house, or multifamily residential dwelling for which the initial building permit is issued on or after July 1, 1990; and
each newly constructed town house for which the initial building permit is issued on or after July 1, 1992.

paragraph.text: In a jurisdiction in which building permits are not issued, a sprinkler system shall be installed in:

subparagraph.text: each dormitory, hotel, lodging or rooming house, or multifamily residential dwelling on which construction begins on or after July 1, 1990; and
each town house on which construction begins on or after July 1, 1992.

subsection.text: If a dwelling unit is not serviced by a public water system, subsections (a) and (b) of this section do not apply.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, if there is clear evidence that an exception will not adversely affect the fire safety of a building or its occupants, the State Fire Marshal or a local authority with jurisdiction over the enforcement of fire and building codes may grant an exception to:

paragraph.text: a requirement of a State or local fire and building code if a sprinkler system is installed in a building as required by this subtitle; or
the sprinkler system requirement of this subtitle if, on or before June 30, 1990:

subparagraph.text: the local authority gave approval to a construction plan for a dormitory, hotel, lodging or rooming house, multifamily residential unit, or town house; and
the approved plan did not include the installation of a sprinkler system as required by this subtitle.

subsection.text: The State Fire Marshal or a local authority may not grant an exception under this section to a smoke detector requirement.
A person may not knowingly violate this subtitle.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 10 days or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
This subtitle:

paragraph.text: is in addition to any existing fire safety laws; and
does not limit the authority of the State Fire Prevention Commission or State Fire Marshal to act under existing fire safety laws.

subsection.text: If there is clear evidence that equivalent protection of human life will be provided as required by this subtitle, exceptions to this subtitle may be made by:

paragraph.text: the State Fire Prevention Commission;
the State Fire Marshal;
a county fire chief;
a fire administrator with responsibility for code enforcement; and
in Baltimore City, the Board of Fire Commissioners or the Chief of the Fire Department.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not prevent a county or municipal corporation from enacting more stringent laws to govern the installation of fire sprinkler systems.

section.text: A county fire chief, fire administrator, or municipal fire chief may enforce this subtitle.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, each hotel or motel with 10 or more units for which a contract for construction is executed after July 1, 1989, shall have installed a fast response residential fire sprinkler system that is intended:

paragraph.text: to detect and control a fire automatically;
to provide improved protection against injury, loss of life, and property damage;
to maintain survivable conditions in the room of fire origin; and
to improve the chance for occupants to escape or be evacuated.

subsection.text: A hotel or motel need not install a fast response residential fire sprinkler system if:

paragraph.text: the hotel or motel is a one or two story building; and

all occupants are able to exit directly to the exterior of the building and not only to a central corridor through an approved exit door, as those terms are used in the most recent edition of the National Fire Protection Association Life Safety Code adopted by the State Fire Prevention Commission.

section.text: Each fast response residential fire sprinkler system installed shall:

paragraph.text: be designed and constructed in accordance with accepted engineering practices; and
comply with standards and regulations developed and adopted by:

subparagraph.text: the State Fire Prevention Commission;
a county fire chief;
a fire administrator with responsibility for code enforcement; or
in Baltimore City, the Chief of the Fire Department.

section.text: When evaluating and approving a builder’s overall site development and construction plans, the cost of the builder’s installation of fast response residential fire sprinkler systems shall be considered by:

paragraph.text: local building officials;
local fire chiefs;
the State Fire Prevention Commission;
the State Fire Marshal;
fire administrators with responsibility for code enforcement; and
in Baltimore City, the Chief of the Fire Department.

section.text: A person who violates this subtitle is subject to the penalty provided in § 6-601 of this article.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “High–rise building” means a building for human occupancy that is:

subparagraph.text: four or more stories above grade level; or
over 45 feet in height.

paragraph.text: “High–rise building” does not include:

subparagraph.text: a structure or building used exclusively for open air parking; or
a building used exclusively for agricultural purposes.

subsection.text: “Local fire department” means a career or volunteer fire department.
“Mobility impaired” means unable to carry objects or to move or travel without the use of an assistive device or service animal.
“Public way” means a paved thoroughfare over 21 feet in width that:

paragraph.text: is located on privately owned and privately maintained property but is designated for public use; or
is publicly owned and publicly maintained.

subsection.text: The purpose of this subtitle is to provide for the physical safety and protection of property of occupants of high-rise buildings in case of fire.

paragraph.text: Without adequate protection, residents of high-rise buildings are dependent on descending multiple flights of steps or jumping from windows when a fire occurs.
For many elderly residents of high-rise buildings, this is physically impossible.
Most fire fighting and rescue operations are also conducted inside the high-rise building, where there are greater obstacles to rescuing occupants and controlling and extinguishing the fire.
Many tragedies could be avoided by installation of automatic fire extinguishing equipment in these situations, usually at no great additional cost to builders.

subsection.text: Each high-rise building constructed after July 1, 1974, shall be protected by a complete automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with accepted engineering practices as approved by the authority with jurisdiction.

paragraph.text: This section does not apply to a building that is less than 75 feet in height above grade level if:

subparagraph.text: the local fire department has at least one approved first line piece of aerial equipment that is capable of reaching the roof of the building; and
accessibility to the building is provided on two sides of the perimeter of the building by a public way that is:

sub-subparagraph.text: kept accessible at all times to the local fire department; and
close enough to the building to allow the fire department aerial equipment to reach 75 feet in height.

paragraph.text: For purposes of this subsection, height above grade level shall be determined by using the lowest elevation of the public way as a reference datum.

subsection.text: An order for compliance with the requirements of § 9-403 of this subtitle that is issued in accordance with the authority granted under Title 6, Subtitle 3 of this article may be appealed to the State Fire Prevention Commission.

An order for compliance with the requirements of § 9-403 of this subtitle that is issued in accordance with the authority granted by a local law, ordinance, or regulation may be appealed as provided by law, ordinance, or regulation of the local jurisdiction.

section.text: For fire safety purposes, the owner of a residential high–rise building with rental units shall provide reasonable written notice annually to all residents of the residential high–rise building to inform residents who are mobility impaired of their right to request a rental unit on the first five floors of the high–rise building if one should become available.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not apply to Washington County.
This subtitle:

paragraph.text: is in addition to any existing fire safety laws; and
does not limit the authority of the State Fire Prevention Commission or State Fire Marshal to act under existing fire safety laws.

section.text: Each hotel, motel, and lodging house shall post in a prominent place in each guest room a notice that states:

paragraph.text: the location of the nearest exits and fire pull stations;
the procedures to be followed if the fire or smoke detector gives warning signals; and
the procedures to be followed if fire or smoke develops.

subsection.text: Each building constructed after July 1, 1977, that is intended to house 50 or more occupants who, because of age, blindness, disability, or physical or mental illness, are unable to evacuate the building without assistance in case of fire, shall be protected throughout the entire building by a system that is:

paragraph.text: designed to detect and extinguish a fire automatically while sounding an alarm; and
installed in accordance with accepted engineering practices approved by the authority with jurisdiction.

An order for compliance with the requirements of this section that is issued in accordance with the authority granted under Title 6, Subtitle 3 of this article may be appealed to the State Fire Prevention Commission.

An order for compliance with the requirements of this section that is issued in accordance with the authority granted by a local law, ordinance, or regulation may be appealed as provided by law, ordinance, or regulation of the local jurisdiction.

section.text: Alternative and equivalent fire and safety requirements are allowed in acute care hospitals in accordance with current nationally recognized codes and standards adopted by the appropriate authority with jurisdiction.

subsection.text: A person who violates this subtitle is subject to the penalties provided in § 6-601 of this article.
A hotel, motel, or lodging house that violates a regulation adopted by the State Fire Prevention Commission is subject to the penalties provided in § 6-601 of this article.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Fire investigator” means an official of the State, a county, or a municipal corporation who is legally designated to have legal responsibility for investigating fires and suppressing arson.
“Fire investigator” includes a fire marshal.

subsection.text: “Insurer” means a person licensed or established by the State to insure property of any kind.

section.text: On request of a fire investigator, an insurer investigating a fire loss of real or personal property shall cooperate with and release to the fire investigator any information it has about the fire loss, including:

paragraph.text: each insurance policy and application for the policy relevant to the fire loss;
policy premium payment records;
previous claims made by the insured for fire loss; and
material that relates to the investigation of the fire loss, proof of loss, and any other relevant evidence.

section.text: If an insurer has reason to suspect that a fire loss to real or personal property of the insured was caused by incendiary means, the insurer shall:

paragraph.text: notify the fire investigator;
provide the fire investigator with all relevant material acquired during the insurer’s investigation of the fire loss;
cooperate with and take any action requested by the fire investigator; and
allow a person, on court order, to inspect any of the insurer’s records that relate to the policy and the fire loss.

section.text: A fire investigator who receives information under this subtitle shall keep the information confidential until the release of the information is required in accordance with a civil or criminal proceeding.

subsection.text: In the absence of fraud, an insurer or person who provides information on its behalf is not subject to criminal prosecution for an oral or written statement made or other action taken that is necessary to provide information required under this subtitle.
An insurer or person who provides information on its behalf has the immunity from liability described in § 5-409 of the Courts Article.
A person may not purposely:

paragraph.text: refuse to release information that a fire investigator requests under § 9-602 of this subtitle;
refuse to report a fire loss to a fire investigator under §§ 9-602 and 9-603 of this subtitle;
refuse to provide a fire investigator with relevant information required to be provided under §§ 9-602 and 9-603 of this subtitle; or
fail to keep information confidential as required under § 9-604 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 10 days or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.

Subject to subsection (e) of this section, the local governing body of each county and the legislative body of each municipal corporation in the State may adopt by ordinance or resolution a fire prevention code to:

paragraph.text: provide for protection against fires and the removal of fire hazards;
provide for the appointment of inspectors to enforce the fire prevention code; and
establish penalties for violation of the fire prevention code or an ordinance, resolution, or regulation for the prevention of fires or removal of fire hazards.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, a fire prevention code of a county or municipal corporation adopted under this section may incorporate by reference a code or part of a code prepared by a governmental unit or a trade or professional association for general distribution in printed form as a standard or model on any subject that relates to fire prevention, fire hazards, or flammable or dangerous substances.

An amendment to a standard or model code described in paragraph (1) of this subsection is not effective until specifically incorporated into the fire prevention code of the county or municipal corporation.

Except as provided in subsection (e) of this section, the local governing body of a county or legislative body of a municipal corporation may not adopt a fire prevention code under this section until a summary of the proposal is published for at least 3 weeks in one or more newspapers of general circulation in the county or municipal corporation.
The summary shall specify the date for a public hearing on the proposal and shall state that copies of the proposal may be obtained on application to:

subparagraph.text: for a county fire prevention code, the administrative officer of the county; or
for a municipal fire prevention code, the clerk of the municipal corporation.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (e) of this section, a fire prevention code adopted by a county under this section does not apply within a municipal corporation that has adopted a fire prevention code after the effective date of the adoption of the fire prevention code by the municipal corporation.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only to Frederick County.

The summary of the fire prevention code required to be published under subsection (c) of this section shall be published in one or more newspapers of general circulation in the county at least 2 weeks before the adoption of the fire prevention code by the county.
A copy of the fire prevention code proposed for adoption under this section may be obtained on application to the administrative officer of the county.

subsection.text: In this section, “plan review” has the meaning stated in § 6-308 of this article.

paragraph.text: This section applies only to:

subparagraph.text: a county that has adopted a comprehensive nationally recognized fire prevention code as the fire prevention code of the county; or
a municipal corporation that has adopted a comprehensive nationally recognized fire prevention code as the fire prevention code of the municipal corporation.

paragraph.text: This section does not apply to an inspection or plan review that is not within the jurisdiction of or is not conducted by:

subparagraph.text: the county fire prevention bureau or office of county fire marshal; or
the municipal fire prevention bureau or office of municipal fire marshal.

paragraph.text: To ensure compliance with the fire prevention code of the county or municipal corporation, the local governing body of the county or legislative body of the municipal corporation may adopt ordinances or regulations to establish and administer a fee schedule for conducting inspections and plan reviews.

subparagraph.text: The county fire prevention bureau shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: collect the fees established by the local governing body of the county for conducting inspections;
keep records of all fees collected under this section; and
pay all moneys collected under this section into the general fund of the county.

subparagraph.text: The municipal fire prevention bureau shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: collect the fees established by the legislative body of the municipal corporation for conducting inspections;
keep records of all fees collected under this section; and
pay all moneys collected under this section into the general fund of the municipal corporation.

paragraph.text: To ensure that the moneys collected at least cover the costs of conducting inspections and plan reviews, the fee schedule adopted under this section shall be reviewed annually by:

subparagraph.text: for a county, the local governing body of the county and the chief fiscal officer of the county; and
for a municipal corporation, the legislative body of the municipal corporation and the chief fiscal officer of the municipal corporation.

paragraph.text: Plans shall be submitted to the county fire prevention bureau and to the municipal fire prevention bureau for plan review and approval before actual construction of:

subparagraph.text: a new building or addition;
a building undergoing a change of occupancy that requires substantial modification; or
a part of a building that has sustained damage from fire, explosion, or other cause.

paragraph.text: Plans for a building undergoing alterations, renovations, or remodeling that do not require submission under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be submitted for review of maintenance of proper egress and fire protection features.

subparagraph.text: The county fire prevention bureau shall conduct a plan review to ensure compliance with the fire prevention code of the county.
The municipal fire prevention bureau shall conduct a plan review to ensure compliance with the fire prevention code of the municipal corporation.

paragraph.text: The fee for each plan review shall be submitted with the plans.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Combustible material” includes waste paper, rags, shavings, waste, leather, rubber, crates, boxes, barrels, rubbish, or other material that is or may become dangerous as a fire menace.
“Fire official” means:

paragraph.text: a member of a board of fire commissioners of a municipal corporation of the State;
a chief or assistant to the chief of a fire department of a municipal corporation of the State;
an officer or member of a fire department of a municipal corporation of the State acting under the direction of the board of fire commissioners or fire chief; or

a chief, chief engineer, captain, or lieutenant of a volunteer fire company, fire district, or any other organization created for the purpose of and engaged in the work of extinguishing fires in an unincorporated town, municipal corporation, or county of the State.

section.text: This subtitle does not apply to Baltimore County.

paragraph.text: A fire official may inspect a building, structure, or other place under the jurisdiction of the fire official, except the interior of a private dwelling, where combustible material has been allowed to accumulate or where the fire official has reason to believe that combustible material has accumulated or may be accumulated.
At any time and without liability for trespass, a fire official:

subparagraph.text: may enter, at the fire official’s own risk, a building, including a private dwelling, or on premises where a fire is burning, or where there is reasonable cause to believe a fire is burning, to extinguish the fire;
may enter, at the fire official’s own risk, a building, including a private dwelling, or on premises near the scene of a fire to protect the building or premises or to extinguish the fire;
when responding to or operating at a fire or other emergency:

sub-subparagraph.text: may order an individual to leave a building or place in the vicinity of the fire or other emergency to protect the individual from injury;

may order, after consultation with the senior railroad or transportation official present, a convoy, caravan, or train of vehicles, craft, or railway cars to be detached or uncoupled if the fire official determines that to do so is in the interest of safety of individuals or property; and
may enter a building that is in danger of the spread of fire to prevent a potential emergency, including an explosion, in the building; and

subparagraph.text: to maintain order in the vicinity of a fire or other emergency:

sub-subparagraph.text: may direct the actions of firefighters at the fire or other emergency;
may keep bystanders or other individuals at a safe distance from the fire or other emergency and from fire equipment;
may facilitate the speedy movement and operation of fire-fighting equipment and firefighters; and
until the arrival of sufficient police officers, may direct traffic personally or have a subordinate do so to facilitate the movement of traffic.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, a fire official may not inhibit or obstruct members of rescue squads from performing their duties in the vicinity of a fire or other emergency.

A fire official shall give written notice to the occupant of premises where combustible material has accumulated to remove the combustible material from the premises within 48 hours after receipt of the notice, if after an inspection made under this subtitle, the fire official determines that the accumulation of combustible material increases the danger of fire to:

paragraph.text: the premises where the combustible material has accumulated; or
adjacent property.
If the combustible material is not removed from the premises within 48 hours after receipt of a notice under subsection (a) of this section, the fire official may:

subparagraph.text: remove the combustible material from the premises;
send a bill to the occupant of the premises for the cost of the removal; and
certify the cost of the removal to the treasurer of the jurisdiction.

paragraph.text: If the cost of the removal is not paid to the treasurer within 30 days after receipt of the bill, the jurisdiction may bring a civil action against the occupant to recover the cost.
A person may not refuse or neglect to remove combustible material within 48 hours after receipt of a notice under subsection (a) of this section.
A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine of not less than $5 and not exceeding $50 for each violation.

subsection.text: A person may not hinder, obstruct, or refuse to allow a fire inspection under this subtitle.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject for each violation to imprisonment not exceeding 30 days or a fine not less than $10 and not exceeding $100.

section.text: In this subtitle, “fire sprinkler contractor” means a person who designs, installs, inspects, tests, repairs, or modifies a fire sprinkler system.

subsection.text: The State Fire Prevention Commission shall adopt regulations to establish a program to license and regulate fire sprinkler contractors in the State.
The State Fire Prevention Commission shall adopt regulations to:

paragraph.text: define fire sprinkler contractor;
define fire sprinkler system, in a manner that does not conflict with § 12-101(l), (m), or (n) of the Business Occupations and Professions Article;
designate and identify exemptions to the regulations;
establish requirements for licensure including professional and technical standards and requirements for liability insurance;
establish a schedule of fees for licenses that will recover but not exceed the direct and indirect costs associated with the issuance of the licenses; and

establish procedures for the State Fire Marshal to deny, suspend, or revoke the license of a person who fails to comply with any regulation adopted by the State Fire Prevention Commission under this subtitle.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a person may not provide services as a fire sprinkler contractor in the State unless the person is licensed by the State Fire Marshal.
This subtitle does not prohibit:

paragraph.text: inspections and tests of fire sprinkler systems by insurance representatives if the representatives are acting in the performance of their assigned duties;
inspections, tests, and repairs of fire sprinkler systems by full–time maintenance employees of a property owner if the employees:

subparagraph.text: are knowledgeable about fire sprinkler systems; and
are acting in the performance of their assigned duties for the property owner;

paragraph.text: inspections, tests, plan review, and ensuring the maintenance of fire sprinkler systems, emergency maintenance activity on fire sprinkler systems, or restoration to active service of operating or recently operated fire sprinkler systems by members of State, county, municipal, career, or volunteer fire departments, or authorities with jurisdiction if the members are acting in their capacity as members of the fire departments or authorities;

installation of limited area fire sprinkler systems or emergency temporary repairs on fire sprinkler systems performed by master plumbers if the plumbers are acting in accordance with regulations adopted by the State Fire Prevention Commission; or

inspections, tests, preparation of design and specification documents, hydraulic calculations, layout, and plan review of fire sprinkler systems by Maryland professional engineers if the engineers are knowledgeable about fire sprinkler systems.

section.text: The State Fire Marshal shall:

paragraph.text: issue fire sprinkler contractors licenses;
collect license fees established by the State Fire Prevention Commission;
keep records of all fees collected under this subtitle;
pay all money collected under this subtitle into the General Fund; and
investigate complaints related to violations of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly violate this subtitle.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 10 days or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Barbecue grill” means equipment used for outdoor cooking that uses as its heat source electricity or the burning of charcoal, liquid propane gas, or other fuel.

subparagraph.text: “Residential dwelling” means a building or part of a building that provides living or sleeping facilities for one or more individuals.
“Residential dwelling” includes a multifamily residential dwelling, hotel, motel, boardinghouse, lodging house, rooming house, inn, club, or dormitory.
“Residential dwelling” does not include:

sub-subparagraph.text: a single family residential dwelling; or
a multifamily residential dwelling in which the individual dwelling units are arranged in a row, side by side, and not constructed above each other.

subsection.text: In Charles County and Wicomico County, a person may not use a barbecue grill:

paragraph.text: on a balcony of a residential dwelling; and
within 20 feet of any part, including a balcony, of a residential dwelling.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is subject to the penalties of § 6-601 of this article.
In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “1.3 G fireworks” means special fireworks designed primarily to produce visible or audible effects by combustion or explosion.
“1.3 G fireworks” includes:

subparagraph.text: toy torpedoes, railway torpedoes, firecrackers and salutes that do not qualify as 1.4 G fireworks, exhibition display pieces, illuminating projectiles, incendiary projectiles, and incendiary grenades;
smoke projectiles or bombs containing expelling charges but without bursting charges;

flash powders in inner units not exceeding 2 ounces each, flash sheets in interior packages, and flash powder or spreader cartridges containing an amount not exceeding 72 grains of flash powder each; and
flash cartridges consisting of a paper cartridge shell, small arms primer, and flash composition, not exceeding 180 grains, all assembled in one piece.

paragraph.text: “1.4 G fireworks” means common fireworks designed primarily to produce visible effects by combustion.
“1.4 G fireworks” includes:

subparagraph.text: small devices containing less than 2 grains of pyrotechnic composition designed to produce an audible effect;
Roman candles, not exceeding 10 balls, that have a total pyrotechnic composition not exceeding 20 grams and inside tube diameter not exceeding 3/8 inch;
sky rockets with sticks, that have a total pyrotechnic composition not exceeding 20 grams and an inside tube diameter not exceeding 1/2 inch;
helicopter–type rockets that have a total pyrotechnic composition not exceeding 20 grams and an inside tube diameter not exceeding 1/2 inch;
wheels that have a total pyrotechnic composition not exceeding 60 grams for each driver unit or 240 grams for each wheel and an inside tube diameter of driver units not exceeding 1/2 inch;
illuminating torches and colored fire in any form that have a total pyrotechnic composition not exceeding 100 grams each;
dipped sticks that have a pyrotechnic composition containing any perchlorate not exceeding 5 grams;
mines or shells in which the mortar is an integral part, that have a total pyrotechnic composition not exceeding 40 grams;
firecrackers or salutes with casings that have a total pyrotechnic composition not exceeding 2 grains each and external dimensions not exceeding 1 1/2 inches in length or 1/4 inch in diameter; and
novelties that consist of two or more 1.4 G fireworks.

subsection.text: “Explosive composition” means a mixture or substance that, when ignited, may cause such a generation of highly heated gases that the resulting gaseous pressures are capable of producing destructive effects on contiguous objects.
“Finishing and assembling building” means a structure in which fireworks are assembled and packed but are not mixed or pressed.

paragraph.text: “Fireworks” means combustible, implosive or explosive compositions, substances, combinations of substances, or articles that are prepared to produce a visible or audible effect by combustion, explosion, implosion, deflagration, or detonation.
“Fireworks” includes 1.3 G fireworks, 1.4 G fireworks, firecrackers, squibs, rockets, Roman candles, fire balloons, and signal lights.
“Fireworks” does not include:

subparagraph.text: toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns, or other devices that use paper caps that contain 0.25 grains or less of explosive composition if the devices are constructed so that a hand cannot touch the cap when the cap is in place for use;
toy pistol paper caps that contain less than 0.20 grains of explosive composition;
sparklers that do not contain chlorates or perchlorates;
ground–based sparkling devices that are nonaerial and nonexplosive, and are labeled in accordance with the requirements of the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission;
paper wrapped snappers that contain less than 0.03 grains of explosive composition; or
ash–producing pellets known as “snakes” that do not contain mercury and are not regulated by the U.S. Department of Transportation.

paragraph.text: “Fireworks plant” means land and any building on the land used in connection with the manufacture, packaging, repackaging, or processing of fireworks.
“Fireworks plant” includes a storage building used in connection with plant operation.

subsection.text: “Mixing building” means a building primarily used to mix and blend pyrotechnic composition other than wet sparkler mixes.
“Press building” means a building used primarily for pressing or loading pyrotechnic composition into tubes or containers.
“Pyrotechnic composition” means a chemical mixture that on burning and without explosion produces visible or brilliant displays, bright lights, or whistles.
“Storage building” means a structure in which finished fireworks or fireworks in any state of processing are stored, but in which processing or manufacturing is not performed.
This title does not apply to:

paragraph.text: the sale, possession, or use of fireworks to or by the federal government or a state or a political subdivision of a state;
the sale, possession, or use of a combustible or explosive preparation to or by an industrial or commercial business for use as a signal or otherwise in the normal course of business;

the possession or use of a fusee, railroad torpedo, rocket, Very signal cartridge, or other signal device that is essential to and is kept and used to promote safety in the operation of a motor vehicle, boat, railroad, or aircraft;
the use of a flare, signal pistol, or other equipment if used as a signal in an athletic contest or for a similar purpose; or

subject to the terms and conditions of a permit issued by the State Fire Marshal under subsection (b) of this section, the sale, possession, or use of an explosive device or preparation with a slow-burning fuse rope to or by a farmer for controlling destructive animals.

subsection.text: The State Fire Marshal or a State game warden as a representative of the State Fire Marshal may grant a nontransferable permit to a farmer to use an explosive device or preparation described under subsection (a)(5) of this section for controlling destructive animals.
Subject to subsections (b) and (c) of this section, the State Fire Marshal may issue a permit to authorize the discharge of fireworks in a place where the discharge of fireworks is legal.
The State Fire Marshal shall issue a permit to discharge fireworks only if the State Fire Marshal determines that the proposed discharge of fireworks will:

paragraph.text: not endanger health or safety or damage property; and
be supervised by an experienced and qualified person who has previously secured written authority from the State Fire Marshal to discharge fireworks.

subsection.text: A permit to discharge fireworks:

paragraph.text: does not authorize the holder of the permit to possess or discharge fireworks in violation of an ordinance or regulation of the political subdivision where the fireworks are to be discharged; and

does not relieve an applicant for a permit from any requirement to obtain any additional license or authority from the governing body of the political subdivision where the fireworks are to be discharged.

subsection.text: A person must have a permit to discharge fireworks as provided by this subtitle before the person:

paragraph.text: discharges fireworks; or
possesses fireworks with the intent to discharge fireworks or to allow the discharge of fireworks.

subsection.text: An applicant for a permit to discharge fireworks shall:

paragraph.text: apply to the State Fire Marshal for the permit at least 10 days before the date of discharge;
pay to the State Fire Marshal a permit fee of $50; and
post a bond with the State Fire Marshal in accordance with § 10-105 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: If the State Fire Marshal does not receive the application for a permit required under subsection (b) of this section at least 10 days before the date of the discharge, the State Fire Marshal shall charge the applicant a late fee of $50 in addition to all required fees.

The permit fee required under subsection (b)(2) of this section and the late fee required under subsection (c) of this section do not apply to a volunteer fire department or volunteer ambulance and rescue company.
A permit to discharge fireworks is nontransferable.

paragraph.text: Before issuing a permit to discharge fireworks, the State Fire Marshal shall require an applicant to furnish a surety bond with corporate surety approved by the State Fire Marshal or an approved liability and property insurance policy.
The State Fire Marshal shall prescribe the amount of the bond or policy.
The bond or policy:

subparagraph.text: shall be conditioned on the payment of all damages to persons or property caused by the discharge of fireworks described in the permit;
shall be payable to the State; and
may be enforced by a person who suffers damage caused by the discharge of fireworks described in the permit by suit filed in the name of the State for the benefit of the person.

subsection.text: If claims under a bond or policy required under this subtitle are for an amount greater than the penal sum of the bond or amount of the policy, the claims shall be payable pro rata to the amount of the penal sum of the bond or amount of the policy.

section.text: An applicant for a permit shall provide:

paragraph.text: workers’ compensation coverage as required by the Maryland Workers’ Compensation Act; and
for operators not covered by workers’ compensation, approved accident insurance coverage in amounts that the State Fire Marshal prescribes.

section.text: The State Fire Marshal may deputize the chief or another member of a local fire department or another qualified official to inspect, investigate, and receive applications for permits.
A person may not advertise in written or printed form that a fireworks display or discharge will take place in Baltimore City unless the advertisement states:

paragraph.text: that the promoter is covered by a policy of liability insurance; and
the name of the insurer and the policy number of the insurance policy.

section.text: The State Fire Prevention Commission shall adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.

subsection.text: Unless the person holds a permit issued under this subtitle, a person may not:

paragraph.text: discharge fireworks; or
possess fireworks:

subparagraph.text: with intent to discharge or allow the discharge of the fireworks in violation of this subtitle; or
for the purpose of disposing or selling the fireworks to a person for use or discharge without a permit, if a permit is required by this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a person may not sell fireworks to another person without a permit issued under this subtitle.

subparagraph.text: A person licensed by the State Fire Marshal under Subtitle 2 of this title may sell or deliver fireworks to a bona fide distributor, jobber, or wholesaler with a principal place of business in a state where the sale or possession of fireworks is allowed.

The State Fire Marshal may require a person who is an out-of-state distributor, jobber, or wholesaler to submit a certificate issued by the person’s state of operation that demonstrates authority to buy and receive fireworks.

subsection.text: A person who possesses or discharges fireworks in violation of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $250 for each offense.
A person who sells fireworks in violation of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 for each offense.

paragraph.text: At the expense of the owner, the State Fire Marshal shall seize and remove all fireworks possessed or sold in violation of this subtitle.
Fireworks described in paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be forfeited and destroyed.

subsection.text: A person may not sell sparklers or sparkling devices to a person under the age of 16 years.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000.
This section applies to a distributor or wholesaler of sparklers or sparkling devices who:

paragraph.text: intends to conduct business in the State; or
sells, ships, or assigns for sale in the State the products of the distributor or wholesaler.

subsection.text: A distributor or wholesaler shall register annually with the State Fire Marshal on forms the State Fire Marshal provides.
The annual fee for registration under this section is $750.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.

paragraph.text: Only the State Fire Marshal may issue a license to operate a fireworks plant.
A person shall be licensed by the State Fire Marshal before the person may operate a fireworks plant in the State.
A license to operate a fireworks plant issued under this subtitle authorizes the licensee to:

subparagraph.text: manufacture, process, and store 1.4 G fireworks, sparklers, sparkling devices, rockets, and Roman candles as authorized under this subtitle; and
store 1.4 G fireworks and 1.3 G fireworks at an approved location in a storage building approved by the State Fire Marshal or a local authority having jurisdiction over local fire prevention codes.

subsection.text: Each fireworks plant in the State, regardless of when constructed, must conform to the requirements of this subtitle before a license to operate a fireworks plant is issued or renewed.
Before the State Fire Marshal issues or renews a license to operate a fireworks plant:

paragraph.text: the State Fire Marshal, or a designee of the State Fire Marshal, shall:

subparagraph.text: inspect the fireworks plant for compliance with this subtitle and regulations adopted under this subtitle; and
find the fireworks plant to be in full compliance with this subtitle and the regulations adopted under this subtitle;

paragraph.text: each unit of the State or political subdivision of the State that is responsible for determining compliance with other applicable statutes, ordinances, and regulations shall:

subparagraph.text: determine whether the fireworks plant is in compliance with the other applicable statutes, ordinances, and regulations; and
report the results of the determination to the State Fire Marshal; and

paragraph.text: the State Fire Marshal must receive a report from each unit of the State or political subdivision of the State that is responsible for determining compliance with applicable statutes, ordinances, and regulations, that states that the fireworks plant is in full compliance.

subsection.text: The State Fire Marshal may deny a license to operate a fireworks plant to an applicant who has been convicted of a felony under federal law or any state law.
The term of a license may not exceed 1 year.
An applicant shall pay to the State Fire Marshal a license fee of $750.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) or (3) of this subsection, if a licensee commits a violation of this subtitle or a regulation adopted by the State Fire Prevention Commission under this subtitle, the State Fire Marshal may suspend the license of the licensee for not more than 30 days.

The State Fire Marshal shall suspend for 30 days the license of a licensee who, within 5 years of committing a first violation, commits a second violation of this subtitle or a regulation adopted by the State Fire Prevention Commission under this subtitle.

The State Fire Marshal shall revoke the license of a licensee who, within 5 years of committing a first violation, commits a third violation, of this subtitle or a regulation adopted by the State Fire Prevention Commission under this subtitle.
On suspending or revoking a license under this subsection, the State Fire Marshal shall:

subparagraph.text: file and keep a statement of the nature of the violation that resulted in the suspension or revocation; and
provide a copy of the statement to the owner and the operator of the fireworks plant.
If the State Fire Marshal suspends, revokes, or refuses to renew a license, the State Fire Marshal or designee of the State Fire Marshal shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: determine whether the continued presence of explosive composition within the fireworks plant constitutes a danger to public safety; and
if there is a finding of a danger to public safety, remove and dispose of the explosive composition.

subparagraph.text: If the State Fire Marshal determines that the danger to public safety under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph is a clear and present danger, the State Fire Marshal or designee of the State Fire Marshal shall remove and dispose of the explosive composition even if an appeal is pending.

subsection.text: As necessary or advisable to protect the safety of employees of a fireworks plant and the public and to protect public property, the State Fire Prevention Commission shall:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations consistent with this subtitle; and
enforce the regulations through the office of the State Fire Marshal.

subsection.text: The scope of the regulations adopted under this section may include:

paragraph.text: the implementation of this subtitle; and
requirements relating to:

subparagraph.text: the location, construction, arrangement, and operation of a fireworks plant;
personnel;
public liability and workers’ compensation insurance; and
fireworks plant safety.

subsection.text: The State Fire Marshal or a designee of the State Fire Marshal shall inspect periodically each fireworks plant owned or operated by a person licensed under this subtitle.
An inspection under this section shall include all aspects of fireworks plant operation.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, a mixing building or storage building of a fireworks plant shall be located at least:

subparagraph.text: 1,000 feet from a school, church, hospital, place of public assembly, or gasoline or fuel oil storage building or service station; and
200 feet from any other inhabited building, a highway, or a railroad.

paragraph.text: A building within a fireworks plant that contains hazardous mixes or items may not be located nearer to the fireworks plant property line than is authorized under regulations adopted by the State Fire Prevention Commission.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, a finishing and assembling building shall be located at least:

sub-subparagraph.text: 75 feet from any other finishing and assembling building; and
200 feet from any storage building used primarily to store finished fireworks other than sparklers.

subparagraph.text: If a candle building or rocket press building of a fireworks plant is constructed of approved fire-resistant materials, is barricaded, and otherwise meets the requirements of the State Fire Prevention Commission, the building shall be located at least 50 feet from other finishing and assembling buildings.

paragraph.text: A licensee may package and repackage 1.4 G fireworks in finished form in a storage building if there is a minimum separation distance of 25 feet between the packaging area and any stored fireworks.
Except as provided under paragraph (3)(ii) of this subsection, a distance prescribed under this section may not be reduced because of the presence of a barricade or earth cover.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a fireworks plant shall be completely surrounded by a substantial fence that:

subparagraph.text: is at least 6 feet tall;
contains at least three strands of barbed wire; and
except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, contains openings equipped with suitable gates that are kept securely locked when not in use.

paragraph.text: Except for an office building in which processing or storage is prohibited, each building in a fireworks plant shall be located within the fence required under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

The main gate of the plant may be left open during the regular hours of plant operation if the gate is within the unobstructed view and under the observation of authorized responsible employees or guards.
The licensee shall post conspicuous signs at least every 500 feet along the fence of the fireworks plant that state “WARNING - NO SMOKING - NO TRESPASSING”.

subsection.text: Each building in a fireworks plant shall be constructed as provided in this section.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies to a building that is constructed or improved after July 1, 1970, or to which an addition is made after July 1, 1970.
The following buildings in a fireworks plant shall have exterior walls and roofs that are constructed of noncombustible material and shall be constructed to be frangible:

subparagraph.text: a finishing and assembling building;
a press building; and
a mixing building.

subsection.text: A building in a fireworks plant may not contain a basement or exceed one story.

paragraph.text: The interior wall surfaces and ceilings of a building in a fireworks plant shall:

subparagraph.text: be smooth, free from cracks and crevices, and fire resistant; and
contain a minimum number of horizontal ledges on which dust may accumulate.
A floor or work surface in a building in a fireworks plant may not have cracks or crevices in which explosives may lodge.
A wall joint or opening for wiring or plumbing in a building in a fireworks plant shall be sealed to prevent entry of dust.

paragraph.text: A mixing building or press building in a fireworks plant shall contain conductive flooring that is properly grounded.

subsection.text: A building in a fireworks plant shall be heated by:

paragraph.text: steam;
indirectly radiating hot air;
hot water; or
any other means approved by the State Fire Prevention Commission.
All electric wiring in a fireworks plant shall be permanent and installed in approved conduits.
All electrical service shall comply with applicable electrical codes.
Temporary or loose electric wiring or extension lights may not be used except:

subparagraph.text: during repair operations while using approved temporary extensions; and
after the area has been cleared of all explosive composition and washed of dust.

paragraph.text: Each fireworks plant shall have a master switch that:

subparagraph.text: is located at the point where electric current enters the fireworks plant; and
on being opened, immediately cuts off all electric current to the fireworks plant.

paragraph.text: Other than in a warehouse, an open knife switch may not be used inside a building of a fireworks plant.
Artificial lighting in a fireworks plant shall be provided by electric, vapor-proof, keyless lamps.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, each building shall contain:

subparagraph.text: at least two exits for each work area; and
at least two exits from the building.

paragraph.text: Each small building with a designated capacity of one individual may have only one exit.
Each exit shall be at least 30 inches wide.
Exits shall be located:

subparagraph.text: so that the path of travel from the work area is unobstructed; and
at opposite ends of the work area.

paragraph.text: An exit door shall:

subparagraph.text: open outward;
remain unlocked during the hours that the work area or building is occupied; and
remain unobstructed.

subsection.text: Each building in a fireworks plant shall be equipped as provided in this section.

paragraph.text: A stove, an exposed flame, or an electric heater may not be used in a fireworks plant, except in a boiler room, machine shop, office building, pump house, or lavatory in which fireworks, fireworks components, or volatile chemicals are prohibited.
If a unit heater is located inside a building that could, at any time, contain explosive composition:

subparagraph.text: the heater shall be equipped with an explosion-proof motor; and
the switches controlling the motor of the unit heater shall be located outside the building in which the motor is located.

subsection.text: An electric motor, fan, open switch, or other device capable of producing an open spark shall be located:

paragraph.text: outside any building in a fireworks plant that at any time contains explosive composition; and
in a manner so that an open spark cannot be introduced into a building in a fireworks plant that, at any time, contains explosive composition.

subsection.text: A press or other mechanical device located in a building in a fireworks plant that, at any time, contains explosive composition shall be properly grounded to prevent the accumulation of static electricity.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “explosive composition” or “pyrotechnic composition” includes raw materials, materials being processed, and finished products.

By regulation, the State Fire Prevention Commission shall determine the maximum amount of explosive composition or pyrotechnic composition that may be safely kept in any building in a fireworks plant at any time.
A licensee shall:

subparagraph.text: post conspicuously on each building in the fireworks plant, the limits on the amount of explosive composition or pyrotechnic composition authorized under this subsection; and
strictly comply with the limits.

paragraph.text: A licensee shall keep each building in a fireworks plant clean, orderly, and free from accumulated dust or rubbish.

If powder or other explosive materials are spilled on the floor of a building in a fireworks plant, the licensee shall ensure that the floor is cleaned immediately and that the powder or materials are removed immediately from the building.
A licensee shall ensure that rags, combustible and explosive scrap, and paper are:

subparagraph.text: kept separate from each other; and
placed in approved marked containers.

paragraph.text: A licensee shall ensure that waste and rejected hazardous materials are:

subparagraph.text: removed daily from each building;
removed at regular intervals from the fireworks plant; and
destroyed by submersion in water or by burning.

paragraph.text: A licensee shall ensure that nonhazardous waste is:

subparagraph.text: removed at regular intervals from the fireworks plant; and
disposed of in a landfill system or by other suitable means.

subsection.text: A licensee shall ensure that adequate and appropriate fire extinguishers that meet the State Fire Prevention Code are:

paragraph.text: kept in each building in a fireworks plant; and
readily accessible at all times.

Unless an individual has signed into a log and has stated in writing the purpose of the individual’s visit to the fireworks plant, a licensee may not allow entry into a fireworks plant by an individual other than:

subparagraph.text: an authorized employee; or
a representative of a unit of the federal government, a state government, or a political subdivision, having jurisdiction over the fireworks plant.

paragraph.text: A licensee shall:

subparagraph.text: maintain the log of visitors to the fireworks plant for at least 2 years; and
make the log available for inspection by the State Fire Marshal or a representative of the State Fire Marshal.

paragraph.text: All visitors shall wear conductive footwear.
There shall be at least one competent security guard present on duty whenever any explosive composition is located within a fireworks plant.
The security guard:

subparagraph.text: may not sleep on duty; and
shall patrol the entire fireworks plant regularly when the fireworks plant is not in operation.

subsection.text: A licensee may test fireworks or their components only in an area that is:

paragraph.text: set aside for that purpose; and
located at a safe distance from any fireworks plant building or other structure, considering the nature of the materials being tested.

subsection.text: A licensee may experiment with fireworks, pyrotechnics, or their components only as authorized by the State Fire Marshal.

paragraph.text: The licensee shall designate an employee in each fireworks plant as safety officer.
When an employee of a fireworks plant begins employment in the fireworks plant and at least annually thereafter, the safety officer shall instruct the employee formally about:

subparagraph.text: the provisions of this subtitle;
regulations adopted by the State Fire Prevention Commission;
proper methods and procedures in fireworks plants;
safety requirements and procedures for handling explosives and fireworks; and
other subjects that the State Fire Prevention Commission requires.

paragraph.text: After receiving each course of instruction, the employee shall sign a statement that the employee:

subparagraph.text: has received instruction in the subjects required under paragraph (2) of this subsection; and
understands the requirements for safe practices.

paragraph.text: The statement required under paragraph (3) of this subsection shall be:

subparagraph.text: filed in the personnel records of the fireworks plant; and
made available for inspection by the State Fire Marshal.

subsection.text: A licensee shall post conspicuously in each building signs stating the maximum number of workers and visitors who may be present in the building at any one time.

paragraph.text: A licensee shall:

subparagraph.text: provide cotton working uniforms and conductive shoes to each individual working in a mixing building and press building in a fireworks plant;
provide facilities for:

sub-subparagraph.text: individuals to change into and out of uniforms; and
the safekeeping of clothing;

subparagraph.text: wash uniforms frequently to prevent the accumulation of explosive composition on the uniforms; and
provide for employees washing and showering facilities designated by the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene.
Each individual working in a mixing building and press building in a fireworks plant shall wear the cotton uniforms and conductive shoes that the licensee provides.
Each individual working in a production building in a fireworks plant shall wear the type of eye protection designated by the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene.
Each individual working in a mixing area in a fireworks plant shall wear the type of respirator designated by the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene.

paragraph.text: An individual may not wear the uniform outside the fireworks plant.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a person may not smoke or carry a lighted pipe, cigarette, cigar, match, lighter, or open flame inside the fence of a fireworks plant.
A licensee may allow smoking in:

subparagraph.text: an office building; or
another building if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the building is used exclusively as a lunchroom or for rest rooms; and
the presence of fireworks or any explosive composition in the building is prohibited.

paragraph.text: The licensee shall mark locations in which smoking is authorized.
Smoking locations shall contain:

subparagraph.text: suitable receptacles for cigarette and cigar butts and pipe heels; and
at least one serviceable fire extinguisher of a type that is acceptable to the State Fire Marshal.

paragraph.text: A person whose clothing is so contaminated with explosives or other dangerous materials as to possibly endanger the safety of other fireworks plant personnel may not be allowed in a smoking location.
A person may not bring into a finishing and assembling building, press building, mixing building, or storage building:

subparagraph.text: a match, cigarette lighter, or other flame-producing device; or
a key, knife, coin, or other personal article made of metal.

paragraph.text: A person shall only use properly maintained and nonferrous safety hand tools in any area of a fireworks plant in which there is a danger that materials may be ignited by sparks.

subsection.text: A person may not:

paragraph.text: enter or attempt to enter a fireworks plant while:

subparagraph.text: possessing liquor or narcotics; or
under the influence of liquor or narcotics; or

paragraph.text: consume intoxicants or narcotics while in a fireworks plant.
A person may not manufacture or process fireworks in the State except in a fireworks plant of a licensee.
A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
Unless otherwise authorized by law, a person under this subtitle may not manufacture:

subparagraph.text: 1.3 G fireworks other than rockets and Roman candles;
fireworks commonly known as “flash and sound”;
products utilizing potassium chlorate; or
explosives.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise authorized under this subtitle or Title 11, Subtitle 1 of this article, a person may not store 1.3 G fireworks other than rockets or Roman candles.
A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.

A person who has been denied a license to operate a fireworks plant in the State or whose license to operate a fireworks plant in the State has been suspended or revoked may not operate that fireworks plant in the State.
A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or a fine not exceeding $2,000 or both.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Dealer” means a person who is engaged in the business of buying or selling explosives.
“Dealer” does not include a manufacturer.

“Explosives” means gunpowder, powders for blasting, high explosives, blasting materials, fuses other than electric circuit breakers, detonators and other detonating agents, smokeless powder, and any chemical compound or mechanical mixture that contains oxidizing and combustible units or other ingredients in such proportions, quantities, or packing that ignition by fire, friction, concussion, percussion, or detonation of any part of the compound or mixture may and is intended to cause an explosion.
“Explosives” includes:

subparagraph.text: bombs and destructive devices designed to operate by chemical, mechanical, or explosive action; and
two or more components that are advertised and sold together with instructions on how to combine the components to create an explosive, as defined in paragraph (1) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: “Explosives” does not include fixed ammunition for small arms, small arms ammunition primers, small arms percussion caps, safety and pyrotechnic fuses, quills, quick and slow matches, friction primers, fireworks, or common matches when used in their original configuration.

subsection.text: “Explosives for use in firearms” means:

paragraph.text: smokeless powder for loading or reloading small arms ammunition; or
black powder for loading or reloading small arms ammunition, antique arms, or replicas of antique arms.

subsection.text: “Local licensing authority” means the sheriff or chief of police of the county or community where the applicant for a license resides or has a regular place of business.
“Manufacturer” means a person who manufactures or otherwise produces explosives.

This subtitle does not apply to explosives while being transported on vessels, vehicles, or railroad cars, or while being held for delivery, if the transportation or delivery is subject to and conforms with regulations adopted by the United States Department of Transportation or United States Coast Guard.
This subtitle does not apply to the receipt, possession, and use of signals required for the safe operation of vessels, motor vehicles, railroad cars, or aircraft by their operators.

section.text: The State Fire Prevention Commission may adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The State Fire Marshal may investigate an explosion or fire that occurs in any place where explosives or ingredients for explosives are manufactured, transported, stored, or used.
The State Fire Marshal may investigate an explosion, accident, or fire if there is reason to believe explosives were involved.

subsection.text: The State Fire Marshal may report the findings of an investigation under subsection (a) of this section to federal or State authorities:

paragraph.text: if the explosion or fire was a willful act, for criminal prosecution of the person causing the willful act; or
if the explosion or fire was accidental, so that precautions may be taken to prevent similar accidents from occurring.
In an investigation under subsection (a) of this section, the employees under the direction of the State Fire Marshal may enter the premises where the explosion or fire has occurred to:

subparagraph.text: examine documents; or
administer oaths to and examine witnesses and other persons concerned.
