engages in an unfair or deceptive trade practice, as defined in § 13–301 of the Commercial Law Article;
willfully or deliberately disregards or violates a building code, electrical code, or law of the State or a local jurisdiction;
while not certified, solicits to engage in or willfully engages in providing electrical inspection services;
while not certified, willfully advertises as a certified nongovernmental electrical inspector;
willfully makes a false statement or misrepresentation in any renewal application or in any other document that the State Fire Marshal requires to be submitted; or
violates any other provision of this subtitle or any regulation adopted by the State Fire Marshal under this subtitle.

subsection.text: In determining the appropriate penalty to be imposed under subsection (a) of this section, the State Fire Marshal shall consider:

paragraph.text: the gravity of the violation;
the good faith of the violator;
the number and gravity of previous violations by the same violator;
the harm caused to the complainant, the public, and the electrical inspector profession;
the assets of the violator; and
any other factors that the State Fire Marshal considers relevant.

subsection.text: Before the State Fire Marshal takes any final action under § 12–612 of this subtitle, the State Fire Marshal shall give the individual against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the State Fire Marshal.
The State Fire Marshal shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The hearing notice shall be sent by certified mail to the last known address of the person at least 10 business days before the hearing.
The State Fire Marshal may administer oaths in connection with any proceeding under this section.
The person may be represented at the hearing by counsel.
If, after due notice, the person against whom the action is contemplated fails to appear for the hearing, the State Fire Marshal may hear and determine the matter.

section.text: Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the State Fire Marshal in a contested case, as defined in § 10–202 of the State Government Article, is entitled to appeal to the Office of Administrative Hearings and to judicial review, as provided in the Administrative Procedure Act.

subsection.text: This section applies in Charles County and St. Mary’s County.
In a county subject to this section, a homeowner may install electrical wiring in a home that is to be used as the homeowner’s residence subject to standards set by the county commissioners.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners of Charles County may adopt regulations to govern the issuance of permits to homeowners under this section.
The county commissioners of St. Mary’s County shall adopt regulations to govern the issuance of permits to homeowners under this section.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a person may not inspect or certify an electrical installation unless the person is certified by the State Fire Marshal.
A person may not willfully make a false statement on an application submitted under this subtitle.
A person who violates this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding $500 or both.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, each elevator and each stairway in a building with three or more levels or floors shall indicate clearly by sign or otherwise which levels or floors are most accessible to the exits of the building.
This requirement does not apply to an elevator or stairway in a dwelling for the personal use of a family.

subsection.text: The owner of a building subject to this section who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $50.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commission” means the State Fire Prevention Commission.
“NFPA 70” means the most recent edition of the National Electrical Code adopted by the Commission.
“NFPA 101” means the most recent edition of the National Life Safety Code adopted by the Commission.
Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, this section applies in Baltimore City.
In Baltimore City, the Baltimore City Fire Department shall enforce this section.
In Baltimore City, appeals concerning this section shall be made to the Baltimore City fire board.
This subsection applies to:

subparagraph.text: a public building or structure owned by the State or a subdivision of the State; and
a hotel, apartment building, lodging house, hospital, nursing home, dormitory, or educational building with:

sub-subparagraph.text: a potential evening occupancy of more than 25 individuals; and
at least 4 stories, excluding attics and basements.

paragraph.text: Each building or structure subject to this subsection shall be equipped with adequate emergency power and lighting in accordance with NFPA 101.

subsection.text: The emergency electrical power supply system required by this section may be powered by generators, battery packs, or other similar devices at the discretion of the owner of the building or structure.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall administer this section.
The Commission shall adopt regulations to enforce this section, including regulations that require:

subparagraph.text: emergency electrical systems in accordance with NFPA 101, to provide sufficient light in halls, corridors, and stairways during outages or blockages of regular services to facilitate the movement of individuals in the event of an emergency;
sufficient exit signs that are adequately lighted to guide individuals on the premises;

sufficient emergency electrical power to operate elevators, electrical facilities in hospital operating rooms, hospital X-ray equipment, and other emergency equipment that are necessary to the proper operation of medical services in hospitals and nursing homes;

adequate emergency electric lighting in accordance with NFPA 101 in each building for commercial, mercantile, industrial, storage, office, or similar purposes if the building is at least 4 stories, excluding attics and basements, and evening occupancy is more than 25 individuals; and
installation and operation of emergency power and lighting in accordance with NFPA 101 and NFPA 70.

For purposes of paragraph (2)(iii) of this subsection, the Commission shall consult with the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene to evaluate the requirements to be adopted for the operation of hospitals and nursing homes.
In making this evaluation, the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene shall consider the size and nature of the particular hospital or nursing home operation.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the State Fire Marshal shall enforce this section and the regulations adopted by the Commission so that individuals on the premises are reasonably protected in the event of an emergency.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to the penalties of § 6-601 of this article.
A person may not use welded clip and seat type connections or other welded “clip-type” connectors as temporary fastening devices in construction that involves the use of structural iron or steel.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $100 for each violation.

A person may not erect structural steel or iron beams or girders with shear composite studs, other studs, or reinforcing shear connectors, unless these devices are attached after the erection is completed of all structural members or forming or decking of a particular floor or deck level or span of a bridge or area between transverse floor beams.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $100 for each violation.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Accessibility lift mechanic” means a person who is engaged in erecting, constructing, wiring, altering, replacing, maintaining, repairing, dismantling, or servicing commercial stairway chairlifts, vertical platform lifts, or incline platform lifts.

“Accessibility lift mechanic specialist” means a person who is licensed as an accessibility lift mechanic and has been certified by the Board to erect, construct, wire, alter, replace, maintain, repair, dismantle, or service private residential elevators.
“Board” means the Elevator Safety Review Board.
“Certificate” means a certificate of registration and inspection issued by the Commissioner to operate an elevator unit.
“Commissioner” means the Commissioner of Labor and Industry or an authorized representative of the Commissioner of Labor and Industry.

“Dumbwaiter” means a hoisting and lowering machine equipped with a car of limited capacity and size that moves in guides in a substantially vertical direction and is used exclusively for carrying material.
“Elevator” means a hoisting and lowering machine equipped with a car or platform that moves in guides in a substantially vertical direction and serves two or more floors of a building or structure.

“Elevator contractor” means a person who is engaged in the business of erecting, constructing, wiring, altering, replacing, maintaining, repairing, dismantling, or servicing elevator or accessibility lift units.
“Elevator mechanic” means a person who is engaged in erecting, constructing, wiring, altering, replacing, maintaining, repairing, dismantling, or servicing elevator or accessibility lift units.

“Elevator refinisher” means a person who is engaged in the refinishing of existing metal and wood elements in elevator cabs, including the stripping of old lacquer on wood and bronze items, staining wood to match existing finishes, cleaning, polishing, oxidizing, painting, lacquering, and the removing of scratches to maintain existing finishes.
“Elevator renovator contractor” means a person who is engaged in the business of performing work:

paragraph.text: on the interior of an elevator involving the removal or installation of the nonstructural surface of the elevator’s wall, ceiling, floor, rail, or handle; and
that does not affect the elevator’s moving operation.

subsection.text: “Elevator renovator mechanic” means a person who performs work:

paragraph.text: on the interior of an elevator involving the removal or installation of the nonstructural surface of the elevator’s wall, ceiling, floor, rail, or handle; and
that does not affect the elevator’s moving operation.

subsection.text: “Elevator unit” includes an elevator, escalator, dumbwaiter, and moving walk.
“Escalator” means a power driven, inclined, continuous stairway used for raising and lowering passengers.
“License” includes:

paragraph.text: an accessibility lift mechanic license;
an elevator contractor license;
an elevator mechanic license;
an elevator renovator contractor license; and
an elevator renovator mechanic license.

subsection.text: “Moving walk” means a type of passenger–carrying device on which passengers stand or walk and in which the passenger–carrying surface remains parallel to its direction of motion and is uninterrupted.

“Safety Code” means the American National Standard/American Society of Mechanical Engineers Safety Code for Elevators, Dumbwaiters, Escalators, and Moving Walks, known as ANSI A17.1–1971, and all subsequent amendments and revisions to it, as adopted by the Commissioner.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
“Third–party qualified elevator inspector” means an inspector who:

paragraph.text: meets the qualifications, insurance requirements, and procedures established by the Commissioner; and

is certified by an organization accredited by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers in accordance with the American National Standard/American Society of Mechanical Engineers Safety Code for Elevators, Dumbwaiters, Escalators, and Moving Walks, known as ANSI A17.1–1971, and all subsequent amendments, and any related consensus standards.

subsection.text: Part II of this subtitle does not apply to an elevator unit that is:

paragraph.text: installed in a privately owned single-family residential dwelling; or
installed in a building or structure under federal control or regulation.

subsection.text: Sections 5-205(j), 5-207, 5-214, 5-215, and 5-216 and Title 5, Subtitle 8 of the Labor and Employment Article apply to Part II of this subtitle.
In this section, “assisted living program” has the meaning stated in § 19–1801 of the Health – General Article.
The Commissioner shall administer and enforce Part II of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner shall adopt regulations that conform generally to the American National Standard/American Society of Mechanical Engineers Safety Code for Elevators, Dumbwaiters, Escalators, and Moving Walks, ANSI Code A17.1–1971, and all subsequent amendments and revisions to it.
If necessary to fulfill the Commissioner’s responsibilities under Part II of this subtitle, the Commissioner shall:

subparagraph.text: adopt regulations that amend standards set forth in the American National Standard/American Society of Mechanical Engineers Safety Code for Elevators, Dumbwaiters, Escalators, and Moving Walks, ANSI Code A17.1–1971, and all subsequent amendments and revisions to it; and
adopt other regulations.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner may adopt regulations to authorize and regulate the installation and inspection of noncommercial elevator units in assisted living programs with five or fewer beds that are licensed by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene under § 19–1804.1 of the Health – General Article.
The regulations shall be consistent with the requirements of § 12–1006 of this title.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may assign duties and functions imposed by Part II of this subtitle to the chief elevator inspector.
The cost of administering Part II of this subtitle is provided for under § 5–204 of the Labor and Employment Article.
Except as otherwise provided in this section, each elevator unit shall be inspected, tested, and maintained in a safe operating condition in accordance with:

paragraph.text: the Safety Code; and
any other regulations adopted by the Commissioner.

subparagraph.text: Subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, an elevator unit installed before July 1, 1955, may be used without being altered or rebuilt to comply with the requirements of the Safety Code.

Each elevator shall be equipped with standard hoistway entrance protection, and each passenger elevator of more than 100 feet per minute contract speed shall be provided with car doors or gates that meet the requirements of the Safety Code.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this subsection, each elevator unit installed before July 1, 1955:

subparagraph.text: shall be maintained in a safe operating condition so as not to create a substantial probability of serious physical harm or death; and
is subject to inspections and tests as required.

paragraph.text: For purposes of this subsection, an alteration of an existing elevator unit is any change made to it other than the repair or replacement of damaged, worn, or broken parts necessary for normal operation.
Each alteration or relocation of an elevator unit installed after January 1, 1975, shall meet the requirements of the Safety Code.

subsection.text: On written request, the Commissioner may grant exceptions from the literal requirements or allow the use of devices or methods other than those specified under the Safety Code and other regulations adopted by the Commissioner if:

paragraph.text: it is evident that the exception is necessary to prevent undue hardship; or
existing conditions prevent practical compliance and in the opinion of the Commissioner reasonable safety can be secured.

subsection.text: An elevator unit may not be operated in a building, structure, or place of employment in the State unless a certificate is issued by the Commissioner.

Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, the Commissioner shall accept certificates of inspection from a political subdivision or municipal corporation instead of the certificate required by subsection (a) of this section.

Except as otherwise provided in this section, each elevator unit owned or to be operated shall be registered with the Commissioner at least 60 days before its planned completion and before it is placed in service.

paragraph.text: The owner or lessee of each elevator unit shall register it on the form provided by the Commissioner.
For each elevator unit registered, the owner or lessee shall provide:

subparagraph.text: its type;
its rating load and speed;
the name of its manufacturer;
its location;
the purpose for which it is used; and
any other information the Commissioner requires.

subsection.text: Under emergency circumstances, an owner or lessee may register an elevator unit with the Commissioner with less than 60 days’ notice in accordance with regulations adopted under Part II of this subtitle.

After an elevator unit is placed in service and a certificate issued pursuant to § 12-811(a) of this subtitle, the owner or lessee shall reregister the elevator unit with the Commissioner 30 days prior to the expiration of the certificate.
A State inspector shall make the following inspections:

paragraph.text: final acceptance inspection of all new elevator units prior to issuance of first certificate;
investigation of accidents and complaints;
follow–up inspections to confirm corrective action;
final acceptance inspection of the modernization or alteration of an elevator unit;
a comprehensive 5–year inspection as defined by regulation;
except as provided by § 12–807(b) of this subtitle, inspections of elevator units owned by the State or a political subdivision; and
quality control monitoring of inspections conducted by third–party qualified elevator inspectors.
A contractor, owner, or lessee shall provide the Commissioner with at least 60 days’ notice of a requested inspection.

If a contractor, owner, or lessee provides the Commissioner with less than 60 days’ notice of a requested inspection that will be conducted by a State inspector, the Commissioner shall schedule the inspection at the convenience of the State subject to the availability of State resources.

For all inspections conducted by a State inspector, the contractor, owner, or lessee of an elevator unit shall pay a fee for an inspection under § 12–810(d) or § 12–812(d)(3) of this subtitle at the following rate:

subparagraph.text: half day (up to 4 hours), not to exceed $250; or
full day (up to 8 hours), not to exceed $500.

paragraph.text: Each fee collected under this subsection shall be paid into the Elevator Safety Review Board Fund established under this subtitle.

A contractor, owner, or lessee who notifies the Commissioner at least 24 hours in advance of a scheduled inspection that the elevator unit does not comply with the requirements of Part II of this subtitle may not be charged a fee under paragraph (1) of this subsection.
An owner shall hire a third–party qualified elevator inspector to conduct all periodic annual inspections that are required by the Safety Code.

An inspection by a third–party qualified elevator inspector shall ensure that the elevator unit complies with the Safety Code and other regulations adopted by the Commissioner under Part II of this subtitle.

The Commissioner shall establish qualifications, insurance requirements, and procedures based on nationally accepted standards that the Commissioner considers necessary to register third–party qualified elevator inspectors under Part II of this subtitle.
Any fees collected by the Commissioner to register third–party qualified elevator inspectors shall be paid into the Elevator Safety Review Board Fund established under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall conduct a final acceptance inspection on completion of the installation, modification, or alteration of an elevator unit before it is placed in service.
The Commissioner shall provide an inspection checklist that specifies the requirements for compliance with the Safety Code and other regulations adopted by the Commissioner.

At least 15 days before a scheduled final acceptance inspection for an elevator unit being installed, modified, or altered in the State, the contractor, owner, or lessee shall submit to the Commissioner a written certification that:

paragraph.text: the elevator plans and construction documents have been reviewed by a third–party qualified elevator inspector;
the third–party qualified elevator inspector has certified that the elevator unit as constructed and installed complies with this subtitle, its regulations, and the Safety Code; and
the elements indicated on the inspection checklist are operational, have been tested, and are functional.

subsection.text: If a State inspector arrives to inspect an elevator unit at the designated time and the elevator unit does not meet the criteria established in subsection (c) of this section, the inspector may cancel the inspection and charge the contractor a fee in accordance with § 12–809 of this subtitle.

If an inspection discloses that an elevator unit complies with the Safety Code and other regulations adopted by the Commissioner, the Commissioner shall issue a certificate to the owner or lessee of the elevator unit.
The certificate shall be posted conspicuously in or on the elevator unit.
While a certificate is in effect, it authorizes the holder to operate the elevator unit in a building, structure, or place of employment in the State.
A certificate is valid for the period indicated on the certificate.

Each elevator unit in the State shall have a periodic annual inspection by a State inspector as provided for in § 12–809(a)(6) of this subtitle or by a third–party qualified elevator inspector as provided for in § 12–809(d) of this subtitle.
Before scheduling an inspection with the Commissioner or a third–party qualified elevator inspector, the contractor, owner, or lessee of an elevator unit shall:

paragraph.text: ensure that the elevator unit is operated, inspected, and repaired in accordance with Part II of this subtitle and the regulations adopted under Part II of this subtitle; and
make inspection, maintenance, and repair records available to the inspector charged with inspecting the elevator unit.
When an inspector conducts an inspection and the elevator unit fails the inspection, the inspector shall issue an inspection checklist that specifies the corrections required.
The inspection checklist shall be on a form provided by the Commissioner and shall specify the requirements for compliance with the Safety Code and other regulations adopted by the Commissioner.

If a State inspector conducts a follow–up inspection to ensure compliance with the corrections specified on the inspection checklist, the contractor, owner, or lessee shall pay a fee in accordance with § 12–809 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: If a State inspector cancels a final acceptance inspection under § 12–810 of this subtitle or if a follow–up inspection is required under § 12–812 of this subtitle, the contractor, owner, or lessee of the elevator unit shall:

paragraph.text: reschedule the inspection with the State inspector; and

ensure that the elevator unit complies with the requirements of Part II of this subtitle, including correcting as necessary any safety hazards or violations of the Safety Code, on the designated date.

subsection.text: A contractor, owner, or lessee shall maintain a copy of any inspection, maintenance, and repair records at a central location in a manner consistent with regulations adopted under Part II of this subtitle.
A contractor, owner, or lessee of an elevator unit shall file with the Commissioner the following records at time intervals set by regulation:

paragraph.text: records of all test reports and inspection reports as defined by regulation; and
records of all incidents or serious injuries as defined by regulation.

subsection.text: All records submitted to the Commissioner electronically shall be in a format and method defined by regulation.

When an inspection by a State inspector discloses that an elevator unit is in unsafe condition so that its continued operation will violate the Safety Code, or any other regulation adopted by the Commissioner under Part II of this subtitle, a citation may be issued and penalties may be assessed in accordance with §§ 12–814.2 and 12–814.3 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: When an inspection by a third–party qualified elevator inspector discloses that an elevator unit is in unsafe condition so that its continued operation will violate the Safety Code, or any other regulation adopted by the Commissioner under Part II of this subtitle, the third–party qualified elevator inspector shall notify the Commissioner immediately.

On notification, the Commissioner shall conduct an inspection of the unsafe condition to determine whether to issue a citation and assess penalties in accordance with §§ 12–814.2 and 12–814.3 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may prohibit use of an elevator unit after determining, based on an inspection, that:

paragraph.text: the elevator unit violates § 12-806 of this subtitle; or
there is a substantial probability that death or serious physical harm could result from continued use of the elevator unit.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall issue a written notice prohibiting use of the elevator unit to the contractor, owner, lessee, or agent in charge of the elevator unit.
A copy of the notice:

paragraph.text: shall be attached to the elevator unit; and
may not be removed until a State inspector determines that the elevator unit complies with this subtitle.

subsection.text: Use of the elevator unit is prohibited while a notice is posted on the elevator unit.
A person aggrieved by the decision to prohibit use of an elevator unit may bring an action to modify or vacate the decision on the ground that it is unlawful or unreasonable.
An action under this section shall be brought in the circuit court for the county where the elevator unit is located.
In a proceeding under this section, a court may not stay an order of the Commissioner unless:

paragraph.text: the court gives the Commissioner notice and an opportunity for a hearing; and
the aggrieved person posts security or meets any other condition that the court considers proper.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (k) of this section, if, after an inspection or investigation, the Commissioner determines that, within the immediately preceding 6 months, an elevator unit is in violation of the Safety Code or another regulation adopted by the Commissioner under Part II of this subtitle, the Commissioner shall issue a citation to the owner.
Each citation under this section shall:

paragraph.text: be in writing;
describe, with particularity, the nature of the alleged violation;
reference the provision of the Safety Code or regulation that is alleged to be in violation; and
set a reasonable period of time for abatement and correction of the alleged violation.

subsection.text: An owner who is issued a citation shall post the citation or a copy of the citation conspicuously at or near the elevator unit alleged to be in violation.
Within a reasonable time after issuance of a citation, the Commissioner shall send by certified mail to the owner:

paragraph.text: notice of the violation with a copy of the citation and proposed penalty; and
notice of the opportunity to request a hearing.

subsection.text: Within 15 days after an owner receives a notice under subsection (d) of this section, the owner may submit a written request for a hearing on the citation and proposed penalty.
If a hearing is not requested within 15 days, the citation, including any penalties, shall become a final order of the Commissioner.

If the owner requests a hearing, the Commissioner may delegate to the Office of Administrative Hearings the authority to hold a hearing and issue proposed findings of fact, conclusions of law, and an order in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.

A decision of an administrative law judge issued in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article shall become a final order of the Commissioner unless, within 15 days after the issuance of the proposed decision:

paragraph.text: the Commissioner orders a review of the proposed decision; or
an owner submits to the Commissioner a written request for a review of the proposed decision.

subsection.text: After review of the proposed order under subsection (h) of this section, whether or not a hearing on the record is held, the Commissioner shall issue an order that, on the basis of findings of fact and conclusions of law, affirms, modifies, or vacates the proposed decision.
An order of the Commissioner under subsection (i) of this section is the final administrative order.

The Commissioner may establish, by regulation, procedures for the issuance of a warning notice instead of a citation for a de minimus violation that has no direct or immediate relationship to health or safety.

If, after investigation, the Commissioner determines that an owner violated the Safety Code or a regulation adopted by the Commissioner under Part II of this subtitle, the Commissioner may assess and collect a civil penalty of up to $5,000 for each elevator unit in violation of the Safety Code or regulations.
In determining the amount of the penalty, the Commissioner shall consider:

paragraph.text: the gravity of the violation;
the owner’s good faith; and
the owner’s history of violations under this subtitle.

subsection.text: If, after investigation, the Commissioner determines that an owner willfully or repeatedly violated the Safety Code or a regulation adopted by the Commissioner under Part II of this subtitle, the Commissioner may assess and collect double the administrative penalties set forth in subsection (a) of this section.

If, after the issuance of a final order affirming a violation of the Safety Code or a regulation adopted by the Commissioner under Part II of this subtitle, an owner fails to correct the violation within 10 days, the Commissioner may impose a civil penalty, not exceeding $1,000 for each day a violation continues, against the owner.
Each civil penalty shall be paid into the General Fund of the State.
Each passenger elevator in a permanent installation used by the public shall have a sign that reads “Warning - Elevators shall not be used in event of fire - Use marked exit stairways”.
The sign described in subsection (a) of this section shall be posted:

paragraph.text: at the entrance to the elevator shaft on each floor; and
directly above the call button.

subsection.text: A sign similar to the sign described in subsection (a) of this section shall be posted within the elevator car.

paragraph.text: The top of each sign may not be more than 6 feet above the floor.
The lettering in the word “warning” shall be at least three-eighths inch high and the rest of the lettering shall be at least one-fourth inch high.

subsection.text: This subsection does not apply to:

paragraph.text: one or two family dwellings; or
buildings under three stories.

subsection.text: Each new building constructed after July 1, 1985, in which at least one elevator is planned, shall have a passenger elevator that can accommodate a horizontally carried and positioned 6 foot 8 inch rescue litter.

paragraph.text: In this section, “repair” has the meaning stated in the Safety Code.

For purposes of this section, repair, renovation, modification, reconstruction, change of occupancy, or addition to an existing building as defined in Subtitle 10 of this title does not constitute a new building.

section.text: There is an Elevator Safety Review Board in the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of the following ten members:

subparagraph.text: as an ex officio member, the Commissioner; and
nine members appointed by the Governor with the advice of the Secretary and with the advice and consent of the Senate.

paragraph.text: Of the nine appointed members of the Board:

subparagraph.text: one shall represent a major elevator manufacturing company or its authorized representative;
one shall represent an elevator servicing company;
one shall represent the architectural design profession;
one shall represent a municipal corporation in the State;
one shall represent a building owner or manager;
one shall represent labor involved in the installation, maintenance, and repair of elevators;
one shall represent the elevator interior renovation industry; and
two shall be members of the public.

paragraph.text: The term of an appointed member is 3 years.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Governor shall appoint a chairman from among the members of the Board.
The chairman shall be the deciding vote if there is a tie vote by the Board.

paragraph.text: The Board shall meet at least once each calendar quarter, at the times and places that it determines.
The Board may hold special meetings as provided in its regulations.

subsection.text: A member of the Board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Board; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: On request of any person and payment of a fee set by the Board, the Board shall certify the licensing status of any person who is the subject of the request.
Each certification under this section:

paragraph.text: shall include a statement of the licensing status of the person who is the subject of the request; and
may include:

subparagraph.text: information about the examination results and other qualifications of that person;
information about the dates of issuance and renewal of the license of that person;
information about any disciplinary action taken against that person; and
if authorized by that person, information about any complaint against that person.

subsection.text: The Board shall collect a fee set by the Board for each certification under this section.

section.text: In addition to any powers set forth elsewhere, the Board may:

paragraph.text: consult with engineering authorities and organizations concerned with standard safety codes about:

subparagraph.text: regulations governing the operation, maintenance, servicing, construction, alteration, installation, and inspection of elevator units; and
qualifications that are adequate, reasonable, and necessary for elevator mechanics and elevator contractors;

paragraph.text: recommend applicable legislation;
adopt bylaws for the conduct of its proceedings; and
adopt regulations to carry out Part III of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Board shall establish fees for the application, issuance, and renewal of licenses issued under Part III of this subtitle.
The total amount of fees established under subsection (a) of this section may not exceed, for the 2–year term of the license:

paragraph.text: $100 per year for an elevator mechanic, elevator renovator mechanic, or accessibility lift mechanic; and
$150 per year for an elevator contractor or elevator renovator contractor.

subsection.text: Each fee for the application, issuance, and renewal of licenses collected by the Board shall be paid into the Elevator Safety Review Board Fund established under this subtitle.
In this section, “Fund” means the Elevator Safety Review Board Fund.
There is an Elevator Safety Review Board Fund.
The purpose of the Fund is to cover the actual documented direct and indirect costs of fulfilling the statutory and regulatory duties of the Board.
The Commissioner shall administer the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The State Treasurer shall hold the Fund separately and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: revenue distributed to the Fund under this subtitle;
money appropriated in the State budget to the Fund;
investment earnings of the Fund; and
any other money from any other source accepted for the benefit of the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund may be used only to cover the actual documented direct and indirect costs of fulfilling the statutory and regulatory duties of the Board.

paragraph.text: The State Treasurer shall invest the money of the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested.
Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be paid into the Fund.

subsection.text: Expenditures from the Fund may be made only in accordance with the State budget.
Any balance in the Fund at the end of June 30 of each fiscal year in excess of 10% of the actual expenses of operating the Elevator Safety Review Board shall revert to the General Fund of the State.
The Legislative Auditor shall audit the accounts and transactions of the Fund as provided in § 2–1220 of the State Government Article.

On or before October 1, 2009, and each year thereafter, subject to § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the Board shall report to the Senate Budget and Taxation Committee, the Senate Finance Committee, the House Appropriations Committee, and the House Economic Matters Committee on the implementation of the Fund.

section.text: The Board exercises its powers, duties, and functions subject to the authority of the Secretary.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in Part III of this subtitle, a person shall be licensed by the Board as an elevator mechanic before the person erects, constructs, wires, alters, replaces, maintains, repairs, dismantles, or services elevator units in the State.

Except as otherwise provided in Part III of this subtitle, a person shall be licensed by the Board as an elevator contractor before the person engages in the business of erecting, constructing, wiring, altering, replacing, maintaining, repairing, dismantling, or servicing elevator units in the State.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in Part III of this subtitle, a person shall be licensed by the Board as an elevator renovator contractor before the person engages in the business of elevator renovating.

By June 1, 2004, a person who engages in the business of elevator renovating for a business incorporated before January 1, 2002, shall be licensed by the Board as an elevator renovator contractor before the person engages in the business of elevator renovating.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in Part III of this subtitle, a person shall be licensed by the Board as an elevator renovator mechanic before the person performs elevator renovator work.

Except as otherwise provided in Part III of this subtitle, a person shall be licensed by the Board as an accessibility lift mechanic before the person erects, constructs, wires, alters, replaces, maintains, repairs, dismantles, or services commercial stairway chairlifts, vertical platform lifts, or incline platform lifts in the State.

paragraph.text: A licensed elevator contractor is not required for removing or dismantling an elevator unit if:

subparagraph.text: the elevator unit is destroyed as a result of a complete demolition of a building; or
a hoistway or wellway is demolished back to the basic support structure.
An individual who works as an elevator apprentice under the direct supervision of a licensed elevator mechanic or licensed elevator renovator mechanic need not obtain a license.
An individual commonly known as an elevator helper who works under the direct supervision of a licensed elevator mechanic or a licensed elevator renovator mechanic need not obtain a license.

paragraph.text: An elevator refinisher need not obtain a license.
A crane mechanic performing work on elevators or lifts located on a port facility owned, leased, or operated by the Maryland Port Administration need not obtain a license.
A person installing a residential stairway chairlift need not obtain a license.
A person who is licensed under this subtitle as an elevator mechanic need not obtain a license to provide the services described in subsection (e) of this section.

The Board shall adopt regulations, including education and experience requirements, to certify accessibility lift mechanic specialists to erect, construct, wire, alter, replace, maintain, repair, dismantle, or service private residential elevators.

Until the Board adopts regulations to certify accessibility lift mechanic specialists to perform work on private residential elevators, an accessibility lift mechanic may provide the services described in paragraph (1) of this subsection.

A candidate actively completing the certification requirements adopted by the Board under paragraph (1) of this subsection may continue to perform that work without certification for up to 4 years after the effective date of the regulations.

subsection.text: An applicant for an elevator mechanic license shall:

subparagraph.text: have an acceptable combination of documented experience and education credits, with at least 3 years of recent and active work experience in the elevator industry, in construction, maintenance, and service or repair, as verified by current and previous employers; and
pass a written examination administered by the Board on the Safety Code;
have completed at least 3 years of recent and active work experience in the elevator industry, in construction, maintenance, and service or repair, as verified by current and previous employers; and

have a certificate of completion of the mechanic examination of a nationally recognized training program for the elevator industry such as the National Elevator Industry Educational Program or its equivalent; or

paragraph.text: have a certificate of completion of an apprenticeship program for elevator mechanics that has standards substantially equivalent to those of Part III of this subtitle and is registered with the Bureau of Apprenticeship and Training of the U.S. Department of Labor or a state apprenticeship council.

subsection.text: An applicant for an elevator contractor license shall have at least 5 years of work experience in the elevator industry in construction, maintenance, service, or repair.
The Board shall adopt regulations governing:

paragraph.text: the qualifications of an applicant for an elevator renovator contractor license and an applicant for an elevator renovator mechanic license; and
the scope of practice of a licensed elevator renovator contractor and a licensed elevator renovator mechanic.
An applicant for an accessibility lift mechanic license shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: have an acceptable combination of documented experience and education credits, with at least 3 years of recent and active experience in the accessibility lift industry, in construction, maintenance, and service or repair, as verified by current and previous employers; and
pass a written examination administered by the Board on the Safety Code;

have an acceptable combination of documented experience and education credits, with at least 3 years of recent and active experience in the accessibility lift industry, in construction, maintenance, and service or repair, as verified by current and previous employers; and
have a certificate from an organization providing an education program for the accessibility industry, such as the Certified Accessibility Technician Program or an equivalent program; or

subparagraph.text: have a certificate of completion of an apprenticeship program for accessibility mechanics that has standards substantially equivalent to those of Part III of this subtitle and is registered with the Bureau of Apprenticeship and Training of the U.S. Department of Labor or a state apprenticeship council.

paragraph.text: The Board may issue a conditional license under this subsection that is effective until January 1, 2017, to a candidate actively completing the educational requirements described in paragraph (1)(ii)2 of this subsection.
An applicant for a license shall:

subparagraph.text: submit to the Board an application on the form that the Board provides;
submit to the Board any proof of eligibility that the Board requires; and
pay to the Board or designee of the Board an application fee set by the Board.

paragraph.text: The application fee is nonrefundable.

subsection.text: Each application shall contain the following information:

paragraph.text: if the applicant is an individual, the name, residence, and business address of the applicant;
if the applicant is a partnership, the name, residence, and business address of each general partner;
if the applicant is a domestic corporation, the name and business address of the corporation and the name and residence address of the principal officer of the corporation;
if the applicant is a corporation other than a domestic corporation, the name and address of the resident agent;
the number of years the applicant has engaged in the business of installing, altering, repairing, renovating, or servicing elevators;

the approximate number of individuals, if any, to be employed by an applicant that is an elevator contractor or elevator renovator contractor and, if applicable, evidence satisfactory to the Board that the employees are or will be covered by workers’ compensation insurance;
evidence satisfactory to the Board that the applicant is or will be covered by general liability, personal injury, and property damage insurance; and
any other information that the Board requires.

subsection.text: An applicant who otherwise qualifies for an elevator mechanic license is entitled to be examined as provided in this section on payment of an examination fee to the Board or designee of the Board.
The Board periodically shall give examinations to applicants at the times and places that the Board determines.
The Board shall give each qualified applicant notice of the time and place of examination.
The Board shall determine the fee, content, scope, and passing score for examinations given under this section.

paragraph.text: The Board may use a testing service to administer the examinations required under this section.
If the Board uses a testing service under this section, the testing service, subject to requirements set by the Board, may:

subparagraph.text: set the times and places of the examinations;
provide notice of the times and places of examinations to the applicants; and
provide any other information that the Board may require the testing service to provide.

subsection.text: The Board or designee of the Board shall provide to the applicant notice of the examination result of the applicant.

Subject to the limitations of this section, the Board may waive the examination requirements of Part III of this subtitle for an individual who is licensed to perform elevator installation, alteration, repair, or service work in another state or a subdivision of another state.
The Board may grant a waiver under this section only if the applicant:

paragraph.text: pays to the Board the appropriate application fee required by Part III of this subtitle; and
provides adequate evidence that the applicant:

subparagraph.text: meets the qualifications otherwise required by Part III of this subtitle;
holds an active license in good standing in the other state or subdivision that is equivalent to a license in this State; and
became licensed in the other state or subdivision after passing an examination that is similar to the examination for which the applicant is seeking the waiver.

subsection.text: The Board may grant a waiver only if the state or subdivision in which the applicant is licensed waives the examination of licensees of this State to a similar extent as this State waives the examination requirements for individuals licensed in that state or subdivision.
If an applicant qualifies for a license under Part III of this subtitle, the Board shall send the applicant a notice that states:

paragraph.text: the applicant has qualified for a license; and
on receipt of a license fee set by the Board, the Board shall issue a license to the applicant.

subsection.text: On payment of the license fee, the Board shall issue a license to each applicant who meets the requirements of Part III of this subtitle.

While an elevator mechanic license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to erect, construct, wire, alter, replace, maintain, repair, dismantle, or service elevator units under the direct supervision of a licensed elevator contractor.

While an elevator contractor license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to engage in the business of erecting, constructing, wiring, altering, replacing, maintaining, repairing, dismantling, or servicing elevator units.
While an elevator renovator contractor license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to engage in the business of performing work:

paragraph.text: on the interior of an elevator involving the removal or installation of the nonstructural surface of the elevator’s wall, ceiling, floor, rail, or handle; and
that does not affect the elevator’s moving operation.

subsection.text: While an elevator renovator mechanic license is in effect, it authorizes the licensee to perform work:

paragraph.text: on the interior of an elevator involving the removal or installation of the nonstructural surface of the elevator’s wall, ceiling, floor, rail, or handle; and
that does not affect the elevator’s moving operation.

subsection.text: While an accessibility lift mechanic license is in effect, the license authorizes the licensee to erect, construct, wire, alter, replace, maintain, repair, dismantle, and service commercial stairway chairlifts, vertical platform lifts, or incline platform lifts under the direct supervision of a licensed elevator contractor.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, unless a license is renewed for a 2-year term as provided in this section, the license expires on the second anniversary of its effective date.
The Secretary may determine that licenses issued under Part III of this subtitle shall expire on a staggered basis.

subsection.text: At least 1 month before a license expires, the Board shall mail to the licensee, at the last known address of the licensee:

paragraph.text: a renewal application form; and
a notice that states:

subparagraph.text: the date on which the current license expires;
the date by which the Board must receive the renewal application for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires; and
the amount of the renewal fee.

subsection.text: Before the license expires, the licensee periodically may renew the license for an additional 2-year term if the licensee:

paragraph.text: otherwise is entitled to be licensed;
pays the renewal fee to the Board; and
submits to the Board a renewal application on the form that the Board provides.

subsection.text: The Board shall adopt regulations to:

paragraph.text: require a demonstration of continuing professional competency for a licensee as a condition of renewal of a license under this section;
establish criteria for continuing education providers;
provide for a temporary waiver of continuing education under specified circumstances; and
set record keeping criteria for approved continuing education providers.

subsection.text: The Board shall renew the license of and issue a renewal certificate to each licensee who meets the requirements of this section.
The Board shall reinstate the license of a person that, for any reason, has failed to renew the license if the person:

paragraph.text: applies to the Board for reinstatement within 2 years after the license expires;
meets the renewal requirements of § 12–833 of this subtitle; and
pays to the Board a reinstatement fee in an amount, not exceeding $100, set by the Board.
If a person has failed to renew a license under § 12–833 of this subtitle for any reason and then applies to the Board for reinstatement more than 2 years after the license has expired, the Board:

subparagraph.text: may require the person to reapply for a license in the same manner as an applicant applies for an original license under this subtitle; or
subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, may reinstate the license.

paragraph.text: The Board may reinstate a license under paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection only if the person:

subparagraph.text: meets the renewal requirements of § 12–833 of this subtitle;
if required by the Board, states reasons why reinstatement should be granted; and
pays to the Board a reinstatement fee in an amount, not exceeding $100, set by the Board.

subsection.text: A licensed elevator contractor shall notify the Board if there are no licensed elevator mechanics available to perform elevator work.

The licensed elevator contractor may request that the Board issue temporary elevator mechanic licenses to individuals certified by the licensed elevator contractor to have an acceptable combination of documented experience and education to perform elevator work without direct and immediate supervision.
An individual certified by a licensed elevator contractor as qualified under subsection (b) of this section shall:

paragraph.text: immediately seek a temporary elevator mechanic license from the Board; and
pay the fee that the Board determines.

subsection.text: A temporary elevator mechanic license is valid for 30 days while the licensee is employed by the licensed elevator contractor that certified the licensee as qualified under subsection (b) of this section.
A temporary elevator mechanic license may be renewed as long as the shortage of licensed elevator mechanics continues.
A licensed elevator contractor shall respond as necessary to ensure public safety if:

paragraph.text: an emergency exists in the State because of disaster, act of God, or work stoppage; and
the number of licensed elevator mechanics in the State is insufficient to cope with the emergency.

subsection.text: Within 5 business days after beginning work that requires an elevator mechanic license, an individual certified by a licensed elevator contractor to have an acceptable combination of documented experience and education to perform elevator work without direct and immediate supervision shall seek an emergency elevator mechanic license from the Board.
The licensed elevator contractor shall provide proof of competency as the Board may require for an individual certified by the licensed elevator contractor under subsection (b) of this section.
The Board shall issue emergency elevator mechanic licenses.
An emergency elevator mechanic license entitles the licensee to the rights and privileges of an elevator mechanic license issued under Part III of this subtitle.
An emergency elevator mechanic license is valid for 30 days for particular elevator units or geographical areas as the Board designates.
The Board shall renew an emergency elevator mechanic license during the existence of an emergency.
The Board may not charge a fee for the issuance or renewal of an emergency elevator mechanic license.
An elevator contractor may not engage in the business of elevator installation, alteration, repair, or service work unless the work of the elevator contractor is covered by:

paragraph.text: general liability insurance in the amount of at least $1,000,000; and
property damage insurance in the amount of at least $500,000.

subsection.text: An applicant for an elevator contractor license shall submit proof of the insurance required under subsection (a) of this section to the Board with the license application.
Unless a licensee meets the insurance requirements of this section, the Board may not renew the license of a licensee to whom the insurance requirements of this section apply.
A licensed elevator contractor shall give the Board notice of the cancellation of insurance at least 10 days before the effective date of the cancellation.

Subject to the hearing provisions of § 12–838 of this subtitle, the Board, on the affirmative vote of a majority of its members then serving, may deny a license to an applicant, refuse to renew a license, reprimand a licensee, or suspend or revoke a license, if the applicant or licensee:

paragraph.text: fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license;
fails to notify the Board or the owner or lessee of an elevator or related mechanism of any condition not in compliance with Part II of this subtitle;
under the laws of the United States or of any state, is convicted of:

subparagraph.text: a felony; or

a misdemeanor that is directly related to the fitness and qualifications of the applicant or licensee to perform services as an elevator contractor, elevator mechanic, elevator renovator contractor, or elevator renovator mechanic;

paragraph.text: transfers the authority granted by a license to another person;
installs, repairs, or maintains an elevator or assists in the installation, repair, or maintenance of an elevator in a negligent or careless manner;
willfully or deliberately disregards and violates a building code, electrical code, or construction law of the State or a county or municipal corporation of the State; or
violates any provision of this subtitle.
Instead of or in addition to reprimanding a licensee or suspending or revoking a license under this section, the Board may impose a penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation.
To determine the amount of the penalty imposed under this subsection, the Board shall consider:

subparagraph.text: the seriousness of the violation;
the harm caused by the violation;
the good faith of the licensee;
the assets of the licensee; and
any history of previous violations by the licensee.

paragraph.text: The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this subsection into the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: The Board shall consider the following facts in the granting, denial, renewal, suspension, or revocation of a license or the reprimand of a licensee when an applicant or licensee is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor described in subsection (a)(3) of this section:

paragraph.text: the nature of the crime;
the relationship of the crime to the activities authorized by the license;

with respect to a felony, the relevance of the conviction to the fitness and qualifications of the applicant or licensee to perform services as an elevator contractor, elevator mechanic, elevator renovator contractor, or elevator renovator mechanic;
the length of time since the conviction; and
the behavior and activities of the applicant or licensee before and after the conviction.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article, before the Board takes any final action under Part III of this subtitle, the Board shall give the person against whom the action is contemplated an opportunity for a hearing before the Board.
The Board shall give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.

section.text: Any person aggrieved by a final decision of the Board in a contested case, as defined in § 10-202 of the State Government Article, may take an appeal as allowed in §§ 10-222 and 10-223 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in Part III of this subtitle, an individual may not perform, attempt to perform, or offer to perform elevator installation, repair, or maintenance work in the State unless licensed by the Board.

Except as otherwise provided in Part III of this subtitle, an individual may not assist, attempt to assist, or offer to assist in performing elevator installation, repair, or maintenance work in the State unless licensed by the Board.
Except as otherwise provided in Part III of this subtitle, an elevator contractor may not employ an elevator mechanic unless the elevator mechanic is licensed by the Board.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a person who violates Part III of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding $100 for each day that the violation continues or both.

A person who knowingly and willfully violates Part III of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.

section.text: Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act, the provisions of this title that create or relate to the Board and any regulations adopted by the Board shall terminate and be of no effect after July 1, 2014.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Authorized inspection agency” means an entity that:

paragraph.text: is accredited in accordance with the National Board of Boiler and Pressure Vessel Inspectors NB–369; or
meets the qualification and definition of the National Board of Boiler and Pressure Vessel Inspectors NB–360.

subsection.text: “Board” means the Board of Boiler Rules.
“Boiler” means:

paragraph.text: a closed vessel in which water is heated, steam is generated, steam is superheated, or a combination of these functions is accomplished, under pressure or vacuum for use externally to the vessel by the direct application of heat from the combustion of fuels or from electricity or nuclear energy; or
a fired unit for heating or vaporizing liquids other than water if the unit is separate from a processing system and is complete within itself.

subsection.text: “Certificate” means a certificate issued by the Chief Boiler Inspector to operate a boiler or pressure vessel.
“Certificate inspection” means an inspection, the report of which is used by the Chief Boiler Inspector to determine whether to issue a certificate.
“Commissioner” means the Commissioner of Labor and Industry.
“Heating boiler” means:

paragraph.text: a steam boiler that operates at pressures not exceeding 15 psig; or
a hot water boiler that operates at pressures not exceeding 160 psig or temperatures not exceeding 250 degrees Fahrenheit.

subsection.text: “High pressure, high temperature water boiler” means a water boiler that operates at pressures exceeding 160 psig or temperatures exceeding 250 degrees Fahrenheit.
“Model steam boiler” means a boiler that is:

paragraph.text: individually fabricated for noncommercial use;
used primarily for demonstration, exhibition, or educational purposes; and
not for profit.

subsection.text: “Power boiler” means a boiler in which steam or other vapor is generated at a pressure of more than 15 psig.

paragraph.text: “Pressure vessel” means a vessel in which the pressure is obtained:

subparagraph.text: from an external source; or
by the application of heat from:

sub-subparagraph.text: an indirect source; or
a direct source other than a boiler.

paragraph.text: “Pressure vessel” does not include a pipe, piping component, or structure whose primary function is to transport fluids.

subsection.text: “Secretary” means the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.

The General Assembly finds that there have been many incidents of danger to public safety because of improper or inadequate construction, installation, maintenance, use, repair, or inspection of boilers and pressure vessels that operate in the State.
The intent of this subtitle is to establish boiler and pressure vessel safety standards in the State to provide a level consistent with the needs of public safety.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, this subtitle applies to all boilers and pressure vessels.
This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a boiler or pressure vessel that is under federal control or regulation;
a pressure vessel that:

subparagraph.text: is used to transport or store compressed gases;
is constructed in compliance with specifications of the U.S. Department of Transportation; and
when charged with gas, is marked, maintained, and periodically requalified for use, as required by the regulations of the U.S. Department of Transportation;

paragraph.text: an air tank that is located on a vehicle that is operating under the rules of other State authorities and is used for carrying passengers or freight;
an air tank that is installed on the right–of–way of a railroad and is used directly in the operation of trains;
a pressure vessel that does not exceed:

subparagraph.text: 5 cubic feet in volume and 250 psig pressure;
1 1/2 cubic feet in volume and 600 psig pressure; or
an inside diameter of 6 inches with no limitation on pressure;

paragraph.text: a pressure vessel that operates at a working pressure not exceeding 15 psig;

subject to subsection (c) of this section, a vessel that contains water under pressure, including a vessel that contains air, the compression of which serves only as a cushion, if neither of the following limitations is exceeded:

subparagraph.text: a design pressure of 300 psig; and
a design temperature of 210 degrees Fahrenheit;

paragraph.text: a hot water supply boiler that is equipped with a safety relief valve and is directly fired with oil, gas, or electricity if none of the following limitations is exceeded:

subparagraph.text: heat input of 200,000 BTU/hour;
water temperature of 210 degrees Fahrenheit; and
nominal water capacity of 120 gallons;

paragraph.text: a mechanical device of any of the following types:

subparagraph.text: a pump;
a compressor;
a turbine;
a generator; or
a hydraulic or pneumatic cylinder; or

paragraph.text: the water–containing part of an air–conditioning or refrigeration system condenser or evaporator:

subparagraph.text: that uses halocarbon refrigerant;
that is constructed in accordance with the requirements of ANSI/ASHRAE Standard 15 (the Safety Code for Mechanical Refrigeration) in effect at the time of construction; and
if neither of the following limitations is exceeded:

sub-subparagraph.text: a design pressure of 300 psig; and
a design temperature of 210 degrees Fahrenheit.

subsection.text: For purposes of subsection (b)(7) of this section, water may contain additives if the ASTM flash point of the aqueous solution at atmospheric pressure is 185 degrees Fahrenheit or higher.
There is a Board of Boiler Rules in the Division of Labor and Industry in the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of the following 10 members:

subparagraph.text: as an ex officio member, the Commissioner; and
nine members appointed by the Governor with the advice of the Secretary and with the advice and consent of the Senate.

paragraph.text: Of the nine appointed members of the Board:

subparagraph.text: one shall be a representative of owners and users of power boilers;
one shall be a representative of owners of agricultural, model, or historical steam engine equipment;
one shall be a representative of owners and users of pressure vessels;
one shall be a representative of manufacturers or assemblers of boilers or pressure vessels;
one shall be a representative of an insurer authorized to insure boilers or pressure vessels;
one shall be a mechanical engineer on the faculty of a recognized engineering college in the State;
one shall be a stationary engineer;
one shall be a professional engineer with boiler or pressure vessel experience; and
one shall be a consumer member.

paragraph.text: The consumer member of the Board:

subparagraph.text: shall be a member of the public;
may not be a licensee or otherwise be subject to regulation by the Board;
may not be required to meet the qualifications for the professional members of the Board; and
may not, within 1 year before appointment, have had a financial interest in or have received compensation from a person regulated by the Board.

paragraph.text: While a member of the Board, the consumer member may not:

subparagraph.text: have a financial interest in or receive compensation from a person regulated by the Board; or
grade any examination given by or for the Board.

paragraph.text: The term of an appointed member is 4 years.
The terms of the appointed members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 2003.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Board shall elect a chairman from among its members.
The Commissioner may not vote.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner may not receive additional compensation as a member of the Board.
An appointed member of the Board:

subparagraph.text: may not receive a salary as a member of the Board; but
is entitled to:

sub-subparagraph.text: compensation in accordance with the State budget; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The exercise or performance of the powers, authority, duties, and functions of the Board under this subtitle is subject to the power and authority of the Secretary.
The Board shall formulate regulations for the safe construction, use, installation, maintenance, repair, and inspection of boilers and pressure vessels in the State.
The regulations formulated by the Board shall conform as nearly as possible to the requirements of:

paragraph.text: this subtitle; and
the following codes as amended and interpreted:

subparagraph.text: the Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers;
the Inspection Code of the National Board of Boiler and Pressure Vessel Inspectors;
the Code for Power Piping, B31.1 of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers;
the Code for Controls and Safety Devices for Automatically Fired Boilers, CSD-1 of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers;
NFPA 85 Boiler and Combustion Systems Hazards Code; and
the Code for Chemical Plant and Petroleum Refinery Piping, B31.3 of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.

subsection.text: The regulations formulated by the Board may be adopted by the Commissioner subject to the approval of the Secretary.

The Board and the Commissioner shall submit proposed amendments to regulations adopted under this subtitle to be consistent with the Maryland Building Rehabilitation Code within 90 days after any amendments to the Maryland Building Rehabilitation Code are adopted by the Department of Housing and Community Development under Subtitle 10 of this title.

paragraph.text: Whenever the position of Chief Boiler Inspector or deputy boiler inspector becomes vacant, the Secretary of Budget and Management as soon as practicable shall conduct a competitive examination in accordance with Title 7 of the State Personnel and Pensions Article.
The examination shall be the same as or equivalent to the examination given by the Board for special inspectors under § 12-907 of this subtitle.
With the approval of the Secretary, the Commissioner shall appoint from the successful candidates a Chief Boiler Inspector or deputy boiler inspector.

subsection.text: If authorized by the Commissioner, the Chief Boiler Inspector shall:

paragraph.text: take action necessary to enforce the regulations adopted under this subtitle and the laws of the State that govern the use of boilers and pressure vessels to which this subtitle applies;

keep a complete record of the type, dimensions, maximum allowable pressure, age, location, and date of the last recorded inspection of each boiler and each pressure vessel to which this subtitle applies;
issue, and for cause shown, suspend or revoke certificates under § 12-911 of this subtitle; and
refer for prosecution each person who violates this subtitle.

subsection.text: Each deputy boiler inspector:

paragraph.text: is responsible to the Chief Boiler Inspector; and
shall perform the duties that the Chief Boiler Inspector directs.

subsection.text: All money received by the Chief Boiler Inspector from fees shall be deposited in the General Fund.

paragraph.text: The following entities may request the Commissioner to issue special inspector commissions:

subparagraph.text: an authorized insurer that insures boilers and pressure vessels in the State; or
an authorized inspection agency.

paragraph.text: On request of an entity described in paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Commissioner may issue a special inspector commission to an individual employed by the entity to serve as a special inspector if the entity and the individual satisfy the requirements of this section.
An applicant for a special inspector commission shall be employed by the entity that requests the special inspector commission.
An applicant for a special inspector commission shall:

subparagraph.text: hold a commission as an inspector of boilers and pressure vessels issued by the National Board of Boiler and Pressure Vessel Inspectors; or
pass the examination given by the Board under subsection (e) of this section.

paragraph.text: The employer of an applicant for a special inspector commission shall:

subparagraph.text: submit to the Commissioner an application on the form that the Commissioner requires; and
pay to the Commissioner a fee of $50.

paragraph.text: The application shall include:

subparagraph.text: the name and qualifications of the individual who will serve as a special inspector; and
evidence that the individual satisfies the requirements of subsection (b) of this section.

subsection.text: By regulation, the Commissioner shall establish insurance requirements that an authorized inspection agency must satisfy before a special inspector commission may be issued to an inspector employed by the authorized inspection agency.

paragraph.text: The Board may give examinations to applicants for special inspector commissions as provided in this subsection.
The examination:

subparagraph.text: shall be in writing;
shall be limited to questions the answers to which will help to determine the fitness and competency of the individual for the intended service; and
may consist of questions prepared by the National Board of Boiler and Pressure Vessel Inspectors.
An applicant who fails the examination may appeal to the Board for a reexamination.
The reexamination shall be given by the Board within 90 days.

paragraph.text: The record of an applicant’s examination shall be available to the applicant and the applicant’s employer.
The fee for an examination or reexamination is $50.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall issue a special inspector commission to each applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.

An inspection by a special inspector of a boiler or pressure vessel insured or pressure vessel operated by the employer of the special inspector, or an inspection by a special inspector employed by an authorized inspection agency, exempts the owner or user of the boiler or pressure vessel from the payment to the State of inspection fees required by this subtitle for the boiler or pressure vessel.
A special inspector may not receive a salary from or have any expenses paid by the State.

paragraph.text: A special inspector commission expires 2 years after its effective date.
Before a special inspector commission expires, the employer of the special inspector may renew the commission if the employer:

subparagraph.text: pays to the Commissioner a renewal fee of $50; and
submits evidence to the Commissioner that the special inspector:

sub-subparagraph.text: meets the standards imposed by this subtitle;
remains in the employment of the employer; and
has been trained on current boiler and pressure vessel technology in accordance with regulations adopted under this subtitle.

subsection.text: Within 30 days after the termination of the employment of a special inspector, the employer shall return the special inspector commission to the Chief Boiler Inspector.

paragraph.text: If an identification card of a special inspector is lost or destroyed, the Commissioner shall issue a new identification card in its place without another examination.
The fee for replacement of an identification card is $50.
After investigation and recommendation by the Board, the Commissioner may suspend the special inspector commission for:

subparagraph.text: incompetence of the special inspector;
untrustworthiness of the special inspector;
willful falsification of any matter or statement contained in the application for the special inspector commission; or
willful falsification of any matter or statement contained in a report of an inspection made by the special inspector.

paragraph.text: Within 10 days after suspending a special inspector commission, the Commissioner shall give written notice of the suspension to the special inspector and the employer of the special inspector.

subparagraph.text: An individual whose special inspector commission has been suspended may appeal to the Board.
At the hearing on the appeal, the individual may be present and represented by counsel.

paragraph.text: An individual whose special inspector commission has been suspended may apply for reinstatement of the commission after 90 days following the date of the suspension.
If the Board has reason to believe that a special inspector is no longer qualified to hold a commission, the Board shall hold a hearing.
The Board shall give at least 10 days’ written notice of the hearing to the special inspector and to the employer of the special inspector.
At the hearing, the special inspector and the employer shall have an opportunity to be heard.
If after the hearing the Board finds that the special inspector is no longer qualified to hold a commission:

subparagraph.text: the Board shall recommend to the Commissioner that the special inspector commission be revoked; and
the Commissioner shall revoke the special inspector commission immediately.

paragraph.text: A new boiler or pressure vessel may not be installed and operated in the State unless:

subparagraph.text: the boiler or pressure vessel conforms to the regulations adopted under this subtitle that govern new construction and installation; or
the Board issues a special installation and operating permit for the boiler or pressure vessel.

paragraph.text: The Board may issue a special installation and operating permit for a boiler or pressure vessel if it:

subparagraph.text: is of special design or construction; and
is not inconsistent with the spirit and safety objectives of the regulations adopted under this subtitle.

subsection.text: For existing boiler and pressure vessel installations:

paragraph.text: the maximum allowable pressure of a boiler or pressure vessel that carries the ASME Code symbol shall be determined by the applicable provisions of the ASME Code under which it was constructed and stamped; and

the maximum allowable pressure of a boiler or pressure vessel that does not carry the ASME Code symbol shall be computed in accordance with the Inspection Code of the National Board of Boiler and Pressure Vessel Inspectors.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not prevent the use, sale, or reinstallation of an existing boiler or pressure vessel if the boiler or pressure vessel:
