paragraph.text: has been made to conform to the regulations adopted under this subtitle that govern existing installations; and
has been inspected and found not to be in an unsafe condition.

subsection.text: The requirements of this section and §§ 12–910 and 12–911 of this subtitle do not apply to:

paragraph.text: a boiler or pressure vessel that is located on a farm and used solely for agricultural purposes;
a heating boiler that is located in a private residence or an apartment house with less than six family units;
a pressure vessel that:

subparagraph.text: contains only water under pressure for domestic supply purposes, including a pressure vessel that contains air, the compression of which serves only as a cushion or airlift pumping system; and
is located in a private residence or an apartment house with less than six family units; or

paragraph.text: an exhibition or antique boiler or pressure vessel, including a steam or gas engine, wheat thresher, or antique tractor, if the boiler or pressure vessel:

subparagraph.text: has been inspected and issued a certificate of inspection by another state that has safety requirements equal to or greater than those of this State; and
has been brought into this State to be used in a temporary exhibit or show.

subsection.text: The Chief Boiler Inspector or a deputy boiler inspector shall have free access, during reasonable hours, to any premises in the State:

paragraph.text: to determine whether a boiler or pressure vessel is being constructed for use or installed in the State in accordance with this subtitle;
to inspect or investigate an accident or explosion that involves a boiler or pressure vessel;
to make an inspection required under this subtitle; or
to investigate an inspection of a special inspector.
In addition to the certificate inspections required under subsection (d) of this section, the Chief Boiler Inspector or a deputy boiler inspector shall:

subparagraph.text: inspect or investigate accidents and explosions involving boilers and pressure vessels;
respond to and investigate complaints about the operation of boilers and pressure vessels; and
monitor the inspections of special inspectors.

paragraph.text: The Chief Boiler Inspector, a deputy boiler inspector, a special inspector, or an authorized inspection agency may:

subparagraph.text: make certificate inspections of the installation of new boilers and pressure vessels; and
make certificate inspections of the repair or alteration of boilers and pressure vessels.

paragraph.text: The Chief Boiler Inspector or a deputy boiler inspector may make a certificate inspection of an antique boiler or pressure vessel or a model steam boiler.
Except as provided in paragraphs (1) through (3) of this subsection, if a boiler or pressure vessel:

subparagraph.text: is insured by an insurer, a special inspector employed by the insurer or employed by an authorized inspection agency under contract with the insurer shall make the inspections required under subsection (d) of this section; or

is not insured by an insurer, the owner shall contract with the Chief Boiler Inspector, a deputy boiler inspector, a special inspector, or an authorized inspection agency to make the inspections required under subsection (d) of this section.
In this paragraph, “private inspector” means an individual who:

sub-subparagraph.text: has a level II or level III certification from the American Society for Nondestructive Testing (ASNT); and

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: is commissioned as a special inspector by the National Board of Boiler and Pressure Vessel Inspectors.

subparagraph.text: If a boiler or pressure vessel is an exhibition or antique boiler or pressure vessel, including a steam or gas engine, wheat thresher, model steam boiler, or antique tractor, that will be used in an exhibit or show for noncommercial purposes, the inspections required under subsection (d) of this section may be made by a private inspector.
If a private inspector makes the inspections required under subsection (d) of this section, the private inspector shall file a report with the Chief Boiler Inspector on the results of the inspection.

If the report of the private inspector shows that the exhibition or antique boiler or pressure vessel complies with the requirements of subsection (d) of this section and the regulations adopted under this subtitle, the Chief Boiler Inspector shall issue a certificate to the owner or user of the exhibition or antique boiler or pressure vessel that authorizes it to be used in an exhibit or show for noncommercial purposes.

paragraph.text: If a boiler or pressure vessel is not insured by an insurer, the Commissioner may contract with an insurer or an authorized inspection agency to have a special inspector who is employed by that insurer or authorized inspection agency make the inspections required under paragraph (1) of this subsection and subsection (d) of this section or conducted under paragraph (2) or (3) of this subsection.

Except for boilers and pressure vessels exempt under subsection (a) of this section or § 12–903 of this subtitle, each boiler and each pressure vessel that is used or proposed to be used in the State shall be inspected, tested, and maintained in a safe operating condition in accordance with the regulations adopted by the Commissioner in conjunction with the Board.
A certificate inspection required under this subsection shall be:

subparagraph.text: an internal inspection if construction allows; or
an inspection that is as complete as possible.
Except for model steam boilers, a power boiler or a high pressure, high temperature water boiler shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: receive a certificate inspection annually; and

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: be externally inspected annually while under pressure, if possible.

subparagraph.text: The Board may extend to 2 years the interval between certificate inspections of a power boiler if:

sub-subparagraph.text: the power boiler has internal continuous water treatment under the general supervision of a professional engineer who has experience in the treatment of boiler water; and

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: the owner or user of the power boiler keeps available, for examination by the Chief Boiler Inspector or by a deputy boiler inspector or special inspector, accurate records that show:
the date, time, and reason that the power boiler is out of service; and

a chemical and physical analysis of samples of the boiler water taken at regular intervals of not more than 48 hours of operation that adequately show the condition of the boiler water and any elements or characteristics of the boiler water that are capable of producing corrosion or other deterioration of the power boiler or its parts.

paragraph.text: A nuclear vessel within the scope of this subtitle shall be inspected and reported in a form and with appropriate information designated by the Board.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, certificate inspections shall be conducted at time intervals set forth in regulations adopted under this subtitle and in accordance with Title 10 of the State Government Article.

The intervals shall protect public safety taking into consideration, consistent with § 12–905 of this subtitle, the design, type, age, extent of automated monitoring, fuel, and operating characteristics of the boiler or pressure vessel.

subsection.text: If, at the discretion of the inspector, a hydrostatic test is considered necessary, the owner or user of a boiler or pressure vessel shall make the hydrostatic test.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, at least 30 days before installing a boiler or pressure vessel covered by this subtitle, the person who will perform the installation shall give the Commissioner notice of the installation in accordance with regulations adopted under this subtitle.

Under emergency circumstances, the person who will perform the installation of a boiler or pressure vessel may give the Commissioner notice of the installation less than 30 days before installation in accordance with regulations adopted under this subtitle.
Except for a cast–iron sectional boiler or pressure vessel, each boiler to be installed in the State shall be inspected:

subparagraph.text: during construction or field assembly, as required by regulations adopted under this subtitle, by the Chief Boiler Inspector, a deputy boiler inspector, a special inspector, or an authorized inspection agency; or
if the boiler is constructed outside the State, by an inspector who holds a commission issued by the National Board of Boiler and Pressure Vessel Inspectors.

paragraph.text: Within 24 hours after an accident or explosion, the owner or user of a boiler or pressure vessel shall give the Chief Boiler Inspector notice of the accident or explosion in accordance with regulations adopted under this subtitle.

On notification or information, the Chief Boiler Inspector or a deputy boiler inspector shall investigate each accident or explosion that involves a boiler or pressure vessel covered by this subtitle.

The Board shall provide for public safety and therefore has jurisdiction over the interpretation and application of the inspection requirements provided in the regulations adopted under this subtitle.
Inspection requirements of operating equipment shall:

subparagraph.text: be in accordance with generally accepted practice; and
be compatible with the actual service conditions, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: previous experience, based on records of performance and maintenance;

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: location, with respect to personnel hazard;

sub-subparagraph.text: provision for related safe operation of controls; and

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: interrelation with other operations outside the scope of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The owner or user of a boiler or pressure vessel required by this subtitle to be inspected by the Chief Boiler Inspector or a deputy boiler inspector shall pay directly to the Chief Boiler Inspector, on completion of the inspection, a fee in accordance with the following schedule:

paragraph.text: certificate inspection:

subparagraph.text: initial certificate inspection of a boiler or pressure vessel not previously inspected in the Stateno charge
follow–up inspection to determine compliance$50

paragraph.text: investigation of an accident or complaintno charge

other inspections, such as an inspection at a fabrication or repair facility, ASME joint review, or National Board of Inspection Code Repair Review, shall be charged at the following rates, and shall include all expenses such as travel and hotel costs:

subparagraph.text: half day (up to 4 hours)$250
full day (up to 8 hours)$500

paragraph.text: Each authorized inspection agency that employs a special inspector shall file with the Chief Boiler Inspector a report on:

subparagraph.text: each certificate inspection; and
any other inspection for which a report is required to be filed under regulations adopted under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The report filed under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: be filed within 30 days after an inspection; and
be in the form required by regulations adopted under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: For each report not filed electronically, the authorized inspection agency shall pay a $5 report filing fee.

Within 24 hours after an inspection, each authorized inspection agency that employs a special inspector shall notify the Chief Boiler Inspector if an inspection reveals a hazardous condition as described in § 12–915(a)(2) of this subtitle that affects the safety of a boiler or pressure vessel.

Each person that operates pressure vessels covered by an owner–user inspection service that meets the requirements of this subtitle shall maintain in its files an inspection record that lists, by a Maryland number and by an abbreviated identification description:

subparagraph.text: each pressure vessel covered by this subtitle;
the date of the last inspection of the pressure vessel; and
the approximate date for the next inspection of the pressure vessel, calculated by applying the appropriate rules for inspection to all data available when the inspection record is compiled.

paragraph.text: The inspection record shall be readily available for examination by the Chief Boiler Inspector or authorized representative during business hours.

subparagraph.text: In addition, the person shall file annually with the Chief Boiler Inspector a statement that:

sub-subparagraph.text: is signed by the professional engineer who supervised the inspections made during the period covered;
states the number of pressure vessels covered by this subtitle that were inspected during the year; and
certifies that each inspection was conducted in accordance with the inspection requirements of this subtitle.

subparagraph.text: The statement shall be accompanied by a filing fee of:

sub-subparagraph.text: $5 per pressure vessel, for a statement that covers not more than 25 pressure vessels;
$125, for a statement that covers more than 25 but less than 101 pressure vessels;
$250, for a statement that covers more than 100 but less than 501 pressure vessels; or
$325, for a statement that covers more than 500 pressure vessels.

subsection.text: If the report filed in accordance with § 12-910(a) of this subtitle shows that a boiler or pressure vessel complies with regulations adopted under this subtitle, the Chief Boiler Inspector shall issue to the owner or user of the boiler or pressure vessel a certificate that bears the date of inspection, specifies the inspection interval, and specifies the maximum pressure under which the boiler or pressure vessel may be operated.

Except as provided in § 12-909(d)(3) of this subtitle, the certificate is valid for the period that corresponds to the interval between certificate inspections as established by regulation under § 12-909 of this subtitle.

If the certificate inspection interval for a boiler or pressure vessel is extended under § 12-909(d)(5) of this subtitle, the Chief Boiler Inspector shall promptly issue a certificate to the owner of the boiler or pressure vessel that bears the new expiration date.

paragraph.text: The certificate shall be posted under glass in the room that contains the boiler or pressure vessel that was inspected.

If the boiler or pressure vessel is not located in a building, the certificate shall be posted in a location convenient to the boiler or pressure vessel that was inspected or in any place where the certificate will be accessible to interested parties.

The Chief Boiler Inspector or an authorized deputy boiler inspector may suspend a certificate at any time when, in the opinion of the inspector, the boiler or pressure vessel for which the certificate was issued:

subparagraph.text: cannot be operated without danger to public safety; or
is found not to comply with regulations adopted under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The suspension of a certificate continues until:

subparagraph.text: the boiler or pressure vessel is made to conform to the regulations adopted under this subtitle; and
the certificate is reinstated.

subsection.text: If a boiler or pressure vessel for which a certificate was issued based on the report of a special inspector ceases to be insured by an authorized insurer, the certificate is invalid.

section.text: The owner or user of a boiler or pressure vessel shall:

paragraph.text: ensure that the boiler or pressure vessel is operated, inspected, and repaired in accordance with this subtitle and regulations adopted under this subtitle;
maintain a copy of inspection, maintenance, and repair records at a central location in accordance with regulations adopted under this subtitle; and
make inspection, maintenance, and repair records available to the inspector required to inspect the boiler or pressure vessel.

subsection.text: An authorized insurer that provides insurance coverage for boilers or pressure vessels in the State shall:

paragraph.text: conduct the certificate inspection for each boiler and pressure vessel that the insurer insures by the date the certificate inspection is due;
file with the Chief Boiler Inspector the reports required under § 12–910 of this subtitle;

develop, maintain, submit, and update, as defined by regulation, a database of all boilers and pressure vessels that the insurer insures in the State and track the date when the certificate inspection for each boiler or pressure vessel is due to ensure that the certificate inspections are due and completed as required under this subtitle; and

subparagraph.text: develop, maintain, and make available to the Commissioner for inspection at the insurer’s place of business in the State a quality assurance program in accordance with regulations adopted under this subtitle; or
submit to the Chief Boiler Inspector evidence of NB–369 accreditation by the National Board of Boiler and Pressure Vessel Inspectors.

subsection.text: If more than one insurer provides insurance coverage for a boiler or pressure vessel or if an owner-user employs an individual with a special inspector commission, the insurers or owner-user:

paragraph.text: may agree to coordinate certificate inspections to ensure that the boiler or pressure vessel is inspected; and
shall ensure that responsibility for the certificate inspection is clearly defined.

section.text: A person who repairs or alters a boiler or pressure vessel shall:

paragraph.text: give notice to and obtain approval from the Chief Boiler Inspector, a deputy boiler inspector, or a special inspector before beginning a repair or alteration that:

subparagraph.text: affects the working pressure or safety of a boiler or pressure vessel; or
involves fusion welding;

paragraph.text: repair the boiler or pressure vessel in accordance with regulations adopted under this subtitle; and
provide reports, as required by regulations adopted under this subtitle, to the Chief Boiler Inspector and the owner of the boiler or pressure vessel.

subsection.text: On inspection, the Chief Boiler Inspector or an authorized deputy boiler inspector may prohibit the use of a boiler or pressure vessel if the inspector determines that:

paragraph.text: the boiler or pressure vessel or part of it violates a standard, safety code, or regulation adopted under this subtitle; and
there is substantial probability that death, serious physical harm, or serious damage to property could result from continued use of the boiler or pressure vessel.

To prohibit the use of a boiler or pressure vessel, the Chief Boiler Inspector or an authorized deputy boiler inspector shall give the owner or the owner’s agent notice that use of the boiler or pressure vessel is prohibited.
The notice shall describe, in detail:

subparagraph.text: the nature of each alleged violation;
the reason for the prohibition from use;
the penalties of this subtitle; and
if appropriate, a recommendation on how to correct the violation.

subsection.text: A copy of the notice under subsection (b) of this section:

paragraph.text: shall be attached to the boiler or pressure vessel; and
may not be removed by any person except the Chief Boiler Inspector or an authorized deputy boiler inspector until the Chief Boiler Inspector or an authorized deputy boiler inspector determines that:

subparagraph.text: each violation described in the notice has been corrected; and
the threat of death, serious physical harm, or serious damage to property resulting from the violation has been eliminated.

subsection.text: Use of a boiler or pressure vessel is prohibited while a notice under subsection (b) of this section is posted on the boiler or pressure vessel.

If the owner or user of a boiler or pressure vessel continues to use a boiler or pressure vessel after notice is issued under subsection (b) of this section, the Commissioner may assess a civil penalty against the owner or user not exceeding $1,000 per day for each boiler or pressure vessel in violation.

paragraph.text: An owner or user who is aggrieved by a decision of the Commissioner, the Chief Boiler Inspector, or an authorized deputy boiler inspector under this section may bring an action to modify or vacate the decision on the ground that it is unlawful.
An action under this subsection may be brought in the Circuit Court for Baltimore City or in the circuit court for the county where the boiler or pressure vessel is located.
In a proceeding under this subsection, a court may not stay a decision of the Commissioner, the Chief Boiler Inspector, or an authorized deputy boiler inspector unless:

subparagraph.text: the court gives the Commissioner notice and an opportunity for a hearing; and
the aggrieved owner or user posts security or meets each condition that the court considers proper.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in § 12-915(e) of this subtitle, the Commissioner may assess a civil penalty not exceeding $5,000 for each violation against a person who:

paragraph.text: violates this subtitle;
violates a regulation adopted or order issued under this subtitle; or
operates in the State a boiler or pressure vessel, except a pressure vessel covered by an owner-user inspection service as provided by this subtitle, without a certificate.

subsection.text: In assessing the appropriateness of a civil penalty under this section, the Commissioner shall give due consideration to:

paragraph.text: the nature or gravity of the violation;
the person’s good faith; and
the person’s history of previous violations.
A person may request a hearing before the Commissioner or the Commissioner’s authorized representative to contest a proposed penalty or an alleged violation of this subtitle.
The Commissioner shall adopt regulations as reasonably necessary to carry out this subsection.

subsection.text: A person may not:

paragraph.text: willfully and persistently operate in the State a boiler or pressure vessel, except a pressure vessel covered by an owner-user inspection service as provided by this subtitle, without a certificate;
operate in the State a boiler or pressure vessel at a pressure exceeding that specified on the certificate; or
interfere with or impede the official duties of the Commissioner, an authorized representative of the Commissioner, or a member of the Board.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject for each violation to imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as the Boiler and Pressure Vessel Safety Act.

The provisions of this subtitle creating the Board and relating to the regulation of boilers or pressure vessels and any regulations adopted under this subtitle are of no effect and may not be enforced after July 1, 2014.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Addition” means an increase in:

paragraph.text: building area;
aggregate floor area;
height; or
number of stories.

subsection.text: “Change of occupancy” means a change in the purpose or level of activity in a building or structure that involves a change in application of the local building code requirements.
“Construction permit application” means an application for a permit or other governmental approval for a rehabilitation project.
“Department” means the Department of Housing and Community Development.

“Existing building” means a building or structure that was erected and occupied, or was issued a certificate of occupancy, at least 1 year before a construction permit application for the building or structure was made to a local jurisdiction, the Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission, or the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission.
“Local jurisdiction” means:

paragraph.text: a county; or
a municipal corporation in the State.

subsection.text: “MBRC” means the Maryland Building Rehabilitation Code.
“Modification” means:

paragraph.text: the reconfiguration of a space;
the addition or elimination of a door or window;
the reconfiguration or extension of a system; or
the installation of any additional equipment.

subsection.text: “Reconstruction” means:

paragraph.text: the reconfiguration of a space that:

subparagraph.text: affects an exit or element of the egress access that is shared by more than a single occupant; or
prevents occupancy of the work area because the existing means of egress and fire protection systems, or their equivalent, are not in place or continuously maintained; or

paragraph.text: extensive modifications.

subsection.text: “Rehabilitation project” means construction work undertaken in an existing building that includes repair, renovation, modification, reconstruction, change of occupancy, or addition.

paragraph.text: “Renovation” means:

subparagraph.text: the change, strengthening, or addition of load bearing elements; or
the refinishing, replacement, bracing, strengthening, upgrading, or extensive repair of existing materials, elements, components, equipment, or fixtures.

paragraph.text: “Renovation” does not include:

subparagraph.text: reconfiguration of a space; or
interior or exterior painting.

subsection.text: “Repair” means the patching, restoration, or minor replacement of materials, elements, components, equipment, or fixtures to maintain them in good or sound condition.
This subtitle is effective notwithstanding any other provisions of law.

This subtitle does not supersede the planning, zoning, or subdivision authority of local jurisdictions, the Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission, or the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission.
There is a Maryland Building Rehabilitation Code Advisory Council.
The Council consists of the following 27 members:

paragraph.text: the Secretary of Housing and Community Development or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation or the Secretary’s designee;
the State Fire Marshal or the Fire Marshal’s designee;
the State Historic Preservation Officer or the Officer’s designee;
the Secretary of Disabilities or the Secretary’s designee; and
the following 22 members appointed by the Governor:

subparagraph.text: one representative of the State Fire Prevention Commission;

four representatives of the building trades who are directly involved or have experience in code setting or code enforcement, including plumbers, electricians, boiler operators, and heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration contractors;
two architects practicing in the State, a significant portion of whose practice includes rehabilitation projects;
one professional engineer;
two contractors specializing in rehabilitation construction;
two representatives of county government;
two representatives of municipal government;
two building code officials serving local government;
one commercial and industrial building owner or developer;
one multifamily building owner or developer;
two local fire officials; and
two members of the public.

subsection.text: The composition of the Council shall reflect the racial, gender, and geographic diversity of the population of the State.

paragraph.text: The term of an appointed member is 4 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of appointed members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Council on October 1, 2003.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
An appointed member may serve no more than two terms.

subsection.text: The Governor shall designate a chairman from among the Council members.
A member of the Council:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation for service on the Council; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.
The Secretary of Housing and Community Development shall appoint the Director of the Council.
The Director is a special appointment in the State Personnel Management System.

subsection.text: The Council shall:

paragraph.text: advise the Department on the development and adoption of and amendments to the MBRC;

provide technical advice on the interpretation of the MBRC to property owners, design professionals, contractors, and code officials and code appeal boards of local jurisdictions, the Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission, and the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission;
develop the MBRC to the extent possible to avoid increased costs to local jurisdictions resulting from implementation of the MBRC; and
to the extent provided in the State budget, provide training on the MBRC for code officials and other public and private construction-related professionals.

The Department, in cooperation with the Maryland Building Rehabilitation Code Advisory Council, the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, and the State Fire Marshal, shall adopt by regulation the Maryland Building Rehabilitation Code.

The MBRC shall be modeled on the nationally applicable recommended rehabilitation provisions developed by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development and the National Association of Home Builders Research Center.

subsection.text: The purpose of the MBRC is to encourage and facilitate the rehabilitation of existing buildings by reducing the cost of and constraints on rehabilitation that result from existing procedures and standards.

Except as otherwise allowed under this subtitle and Subtitles 2, 3, 4, and 5 of this title, and notwithstanding Articles 23A, 25, 25A, 25B, 28, and 29 of the Code and any building codes, mechanical codes, plumbing codes, fire prevention codes, and electrical codes adopted under those articles of the Code, the MBRC applies to all rehabilitation projects for which a construction permit application is received by a local jurisdiction, the Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission, or the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission after adoption of the MBRC.
At a minimum, the MBRC shall:

paragraph.text: maintain a level of safety consistent with existing codes;
provide for multiple categories of work with multiple compliance standards;
be enforceable by local officials using existing enforcement procedures;
apply to the repair, renovation, modification, and reconstruction of, a change of occupancy in, and an addition to, an existing building;
provide an expedited review process for proposed amendments to the MBRC submitted by a local government or an organization that represents local governments; and

provide an opportunity for a person proposing a complex project that involves multiple codes to meet, before submitting a construction permit application, with the local officials, or their designees, responsible for permit approval and enforcement of construction–related laws that apply to the project.

subsection.text: To the extent possible, the meeting provided for under subsection (a)(6) of this section shall include the officials responsible for permit approval and enforcement in any of the following areas that apply to the complex project:

paragraph.text: building code;
mechanical code;
plumbing code;
electrical code;
fire prevention code;
Boiler Safety Code;
energy code;
elevator code; and
local historic preservation ordinances.

subsection.text: The purpose of the meeting provided for under subsection (a)(6) of this section is to anticipate and expedite the resolution of problems that a complex project may have in complying with the MBRC and any other applicable laws.

section.text: Within 90 days after the adoption of the MBRC and any subsequent amendments to the MBRC:

paragraph.text: the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, the State Board of Heating, Ventilation, Air-Conditioning, and Refrigeration Contractors, the State Board of Plumbing, the Commissioner of Labor and Industry, and the Board of Boiler Rules shall submit proposed amendments to their regulations to make the Mechanical Code, the State Plumbing Code, the Boiler Safety Code, and the Elevator Code consistent with the MBRC;
the Department of State Police and the State Fire Prevention Commission shall submit proposed amendments to their regulations to make the State Fire Prevention Code consistent with the MBRC; and

the Department shall submit proposed amendments to its regulations to make the Maryland Building Performance Standards, the Safety Glazing Code, the Energy Code, and the Maryland Accessibility Code consistent with the MBRC.

subsection.text: At least every 3 years, the Department, in cooperation with the Maryland Building Rehabilitation Code Advisory Council, shall review the MBRC and adopt any necessary or desirable amendments.

paragraph.text: A local jurisdiction may adopt amendments to the MBRC that apply only to the local jurisdiction.

A municipal corporation whose authority to adopt or amend a building code is limited, by law, by the authority of the county in which it is located, is not subject to an amendment to the MBRC adopted by the county unless the municipal corporation also adopts the amendment.

subsection.text: To keep current the central database established under § 12-506 of this title, a local jurisdiction that amends the MBRC shall provide a copy of the amendment to the Department:

paragraph.text: at least 15 days before the effective date of the amendment; or
within 5 days after the adoption of an emergency local amendment.

subsection.text: A local jurisdiction that amends the MBRC is not eligible for any funding appropriated above the appropriation in fiscal year 2000 for:

paragraph.text: circuit rider MBRC inspectors provided under the circuit rider program in the Department;
training for the local jurisdiction’s code enforcement officials, as provided for in § 12-1003(h)(4) of this subtitle;
a smart growth mortgage program, to be established by the Department under Title 4, Subtitles 2 and 8 of the Housing and Community Development Article;
the Neighborhood Conservation Program in the Department of Transportation; and
the Rural Legacy Program established under Title 5, Subtitle 9A of the Natural Resources Article.

subsection.text: A local jurisdiction that amends the MBRC is not eligible for a priority under the Department of Transportation’s transportation enhancements programs.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Carbon monoxide alarm” means a device that:

paragraph.text: senses carbon monoxide;
when sensing carbon monoxide, is capable of emitting a distinct and audible sound;
is listed and carries the listing of a nationally recognized testing laboratory approved by the Office of the State Fire Marshal; and
is wired into an alternating current (AC) powerline with secondary battery backup.
“Dwelling” means a building or part of a building that provides living or sleeping facilities for one or more individuals.
“Dwelling” includes a one or two family dwelling, multifamily dwelling, hotel, motel, or dormitory.

subsection.text: “Install” means to attach to the wall or ceiling of a dwelling in accordance with:

paragraph.text: the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) 720 standard for the installation of carbon monoxide warning equipment in dwelling units; and
the manufacturer’s recommendations.

section.text: This subtitle only applies to a dwelling that:

paragraph.text: relies on the combustion of a fossil fuel for heat, ventilation, hot water, or clothes dryer operation; and
is a newly constructed dwelling for which a building permit is issued on or after January 1, 2008.

section.text: A carbon monoxide alarm may be combined with a smoke alarm if the combined device complies with:

paragraph.text: this subtitle;
Title 9 of this article; and
Underwriters Laboratories (UL) standards 217 and 2034.

subsection.text: There must be a carbon monoxide alarm installed in a central location outside of each sleeping area within a dwelling subject to this subtitle.

Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, if there is a centralized alarm system that is capable of emitting a distinct and audible sound to warn all occupants, the owner of a dwelling may install a carbon monoxide alarm within 25 feet of any carbon monoxide–producing fixture and equipment.

section.text: Except as part of routine maintenance, a person may not render a carbon monoxide alarm inoperable.
This subtitle does not prevent a county or municipal corporation from enacting more stringent laws that relate to carbon monoxide alarms.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Department” means the Military Department.
“Maryland Defense Force” means the military force established under Subtitle 5 of this title.
“National Guard” means the Maryland Army National Guard and Maryland Air National Guard.

paragraph.text: “State active duty” means military duty performed in service of the State by a unit or member of the militia under orders issued by the Governor under Article II, § 8 of the Maryland Constitution or § 13-702 of this title.

Unless the Governor specifically provides otherwise, “State active duty” does not include drill periods, preparation for drill periods, annual training, or other equivalent training or duty conducted under orders issued under Title 10 or Title 32 of the United States Code.

subsection.text: This title applies to all uniformed volunteer companies.
A provision of this title may not be repealed or amended by any statute passed by the General Assembly unless the statute explicitly:

paragraph.text: refers to this title as the militia law, or by its other titles, as part of the general laws of the State; and
repeals or amends the referenced provision.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the militia consists of able–bodied individuals who are:

paragraph.text: citizens of the State;
citizens of the United States who take an oath of allegiance to the State; or
of foreign birth and who:

subparagraph.text: are residents of the State; and
have declared their intention to become citizens of the State.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (c) of this section, an individual is exempt from subsection (a) of this section if the individual:

paragraph.text: is exempted by the laws of the United States;
is exempted by the laws of the State;
is a member of a regularly organized fire or police department in a county, city, village, or town;
is a judge or clerk of a court of record;
is a register of wills and deeds;
is a sheriff;
is a member of the clergy;
is a practicing physician;
is a superintendent, officer, or assistant of a hospital or correctional facility;
has been judged mentally incompetent;
is addicted to narcotic drugs; or
has been convicted of an infamous crime.

subsection.text: An individual exempted under subsection (b)(3) through (12) of this section shall be available for military duty in case of war, insurrection, or invasion, or when the danger of war, insurrection, or invasion is imminent.
There are two classes of State militia:

paragraph.text: the organized militia; and
the unorganized militia.

subsection.text: The organized militia of the State consists of:

paragraph.text: the National Guard;
the Inactive National Guard; and
the Maryland Defense Force.

subsection.text: The unorganized militia consists of those individuals described under § 13-202 of this subtitle but who are not regularly enlisted or commissioned in the organized militia.

The general appropriations for the militia shall be exclusively applied to the necessary and contingent expenses of the office of the Adjutant General and to the equipment, maintenance, and general efficiency of the organized militia.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in this title, unless authorized by the Adjutant General, a person may not make a purchase, incur a debt or expense, or expend money for the militia.

subparagraph.text: The Adjutant General shall adopt rules for the receipt and expenditure of all money that comes under the control of the Adjutant General.
The Adjutant General may require bond from persons involved in the receipt and expenditure of money that the Adjutant General designates.

paragraph.text: The commanding officer of an organization or detachment of the organized militia that is on State active duty may purchase necessities that are absolutely required for the immediate use and care of the officer’s command.
If a commanding officer on State active duty makes a purchase under this subsection, the commanding officer shall:

subparagraph.text: take a receipt of the purchase in triplicate; and
promptly submit a report of the purchase through regular channels to the Department’s Finance Officer.

paragraph.text: The report shall contain:

subparagraph.text: a list of the articles purchased;
the price of the articles; and
the receipts.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, the Adjutant General shall audit and pay all bills and military accounts payable by the State.
The Adjutant General shall follow as nearly as possible the financial operating procedures established by the United States Department of Defense.
The Comptroller shall be the auditor of all accounts for property purchased by the Adjutant General.
The Treasurer shall pay an audited military account from an appropriation made by the General Assembly, on the warrant of the Adjutant General, under the direction of the Governor.

section.text: Subject to the provisions of this title and the regulations governing the armed forces of the United States, an individual may be enlisted in the organized militia if the individual:

paragraph.text: is a citizen of the State or has declared an intention to become a citizen of the State;
is able-bodied; and
has good character and temperate habits.

subsection.text: An individual enlisting in the organized militia shall take and subscribe to the following oath of enlistment:

“I do hereby acknowledge to have voluntarily enlisted this ....... day of .........., 20 ....., in the (National Guard) (Maryland Defense Force) of the State of Maryland for the period of ...... year(s), under the conditions prescribed by law, unless sooner discharged by proper authority. I, ..........., do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the United States of America and to the State of Maryland; that I will serve them honestly and faithfully against all their enemies whomsoever; and that I will obey the orders of the President of the United States and the Governor of Maryland and the orders of the officers appointed over me, according to law and regulations.”
Any officer of the organized militia may administer the oath of enlistment.
An organization commander:

paragraph.text: may require those under the command of the organization commander to perform any military duty; and
is responsible to the Governor for the general efficiency of the units of the organized militia under the command of the organization commander.

subsection.text: A commanding officer of a unit is responsible to the officer’s immediate commander for the equipment, drill, instruction, movements, and efficiency of those under the officer’s command.

Each officer or enlisted individual is responsible to the individual’s immediate commanding officer for prompt and unhesitating obedience, proper drill, and the preservation and proper use of the property of the organization, the State, or the United States that is in the individual’s possession.
A unit of the organized militia shall be inspected:

paragraph.text: by an officer detailed for inspection duty, whenever the Governor considers it advisable; and
by an officer of the United States Army or Air Force, as provided by federal law or regulation.

subsection.text: During a time of duty, a commanding officer may arrest for the period of the time of duty an individual who:

paragraph.text: trespasses on a camp ground, parade ground, armory, or other place devoted to that duty;
disrupts in any way the orderly discharge of duty by those under arms; or
interrupts or prevents the passage of troops going to or returning from duty.

subsection.text: A commanding officer may prohibit within the limits of a post, camp ground, place of encampment, parade, or drill that is under the command of the officer:

paragraph.text: the sale or use of alcoholic beverages;
huckster or auction sales; and
gambling.
The Adjutant General, Assistant Adjutants General, officers, warrant officers, and enlisted individuals who are full-time employees of the Department are:

subparagraph.text: military personnel on State active duty; and

entitled to the same pay, including longevity pay, subsistence, per diem, and allowances, as officers, warrant officers, and enlisted individuals of like grade and length of service in the United States Army or Air Force.
For income tax purposes, subsistence and allowances shall be treated in the same way under State law as they are treated by the Internal Revenue Code and federal income tax regulations.
Subsistence and allowances may not be used in calculating the salary base for retirement purposes for an employee who is a member of the Employees’ Retirement System of the State.

subsection.text: An individual who holds more than one of the offices mentioned in subsection (a) of this section simultaneously shall receive only the pay, including longevity pay, subsistence, per diem, and allowances as provided under this section, for a single office.
A military office for which no salary is provided in the State budget is not an office of profit.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies to the period of time that an employee is ordered by the Governor to active military duty in the organized militia of the State for service during:

subparagraph.text: a civil disorder;
a natural disaster;
a labor disorder; or
any other activity requiring support of the State militia.

paragraph.text: The Adjutant General shall secure compensation under the Maryland Workers’ Compensation Act for each officer and enlisted individual of the organized militia by maintaining an insurance policy with the Injured Workers’ Insurance Fund or with a stock corporation or mutual association authorized to transact the business of workers’ compensation insurance in the State.

subparagraph.text: An officer, enlisted individual, or employee of the Department is not entitled to the benefits of this section if the officer, enlisted individual, or employee is injured in the course of employment and has insurance coverage through the federal government that is equal to or better than the coverage provided by this title.

If a benefit provided by the federal government is less than that provided by the Maryland Workers’ Compensation Act, the State and its insurer shall furnish the additional benefit necessary to make up the difference between the benefit provided by the federal government and the similar benefit required under the Maryland Workers’ Compensation Act.

paragraph.text: The insurance provided under this subsection shall only cover incidents that occur after July 1, 1979.

subsection.text: In addition to the benefits under subsection (a) of this section, the Adjutant General shall maintain workers’ compensation insurance for members of the Maryland Defense Force during training.
The Adjutant General shall pay the premiums for the insurance policy required under this section from appropriations for the militia that the Governor includes in the State budget.

section.caption: ** TAKES EFFECT OCTOBER 1, 2013 PER CHAPTER 570 OF 2012 **

paragraph.text: This subsection applies to the period of time that an employee is ordered by the Governor to active military duty in the organized militia of the State for service during:

subparagraph.text: a civil disorder;
a natural disaster;
a labor disorder; or
any other activity requiring support of the State militia.

paragraph.text: The Adjutant General shall secure compensation under the Maryland Workers’ Compensation Act for each officer and enlisted individual of the organized militia by maintaining an insurance policy with the Chesapeake Employers’ Insurance Company or with a stock corporation or mutual association authorized to transact the business of workers’ compensation insurance in the State.

subparagraph.text: An officer, enlisted individual, or employee of the Department is not entitled to the benefits of this section if the officer, enlisted individual, or employee is injured in the course of employment and has insurance coverage through the federal government that is equal to or better than the coverage provided by this title.

If a benefit provided by the federal government is less than that provided by the Maryland Workers’ Compensation Act, the State and its insurer shall furnish the additional benefit necessary to make up the difference between the benefit provided by the federal government and the similar benefit required under the Maryland Workers’ Compensation Act.

paragraph.text: The insurance provided under this subsection shall only cover incidents that occur after July 1, 1979.

subsection.text: In addition to the benefits under subsection (a) of this section, the Adjutant General shall maintain workers’ compensation insurance for members of the Maryland Defense Force during training.
The Adjutant General shall pay the premiums for the insurance policy required under this section from appropriations for the militia that the Governor includes in the State budget.

paragraph.text: To promote efficiency and reward continuous service, the Governor may issue service medals of appropriate designs to officers and enlisted individuals in the organized militia who have completed 5 years or more of continuous service.
The Governor shall adopt regulations to carry out this subsection.
The State may issue appropriate ribbon badges to represent any issued or authorized medal.
An officer or enlisted individual in the organized militia may wear a ribbon badge issued under this subsection as part of the uniform.

section.text: A member of the organized militia, including the member’s conveyance and military property, shall be allowed free passage through any toll gate and over any toll road, bridge, or ferry if the member:

paragraph.text: is traveling to or returning from a parade, encampment, drill, or other duty that the member may be required by law to attend; and
presents an order for duty or identification card.

subsection.text: The Governor may adopt regulations that provide for the retirement of officers and enlisted individuals.
The Governor may order a retired officer or enlisted individual to active duty.

paragraph.text: There is a retired list exclusively restricted to retired officers and enlisted individuals of the organized militia.
The retired list shall be divided into three groups of retired individuals:

subparagraph.text: the National Guard;
the Maryland Defense Force; and
the Inactive National Guard.

subsection.text: Except for the units of the organized militia and the troops of the United States, a body of persons may not associate as a military company or organization or parade in public as a military company or organization without the permission of the Governor.
Except for troops acting under the authority of the President, an armed military force from another state may not enter this State for military duty without the permission of the Governor.

paragraph.text: The Adjutant General may organize a uniformed honor guard from the National Guard or the organized militia to attend the burial service of a deceased veteran if:

subparagraph.text: the commander of an accredited veterans’ organization or a relative or friend of the deceased veteran requests an honor guard to attend the burial service;
a uniformed honor guard from the active armed forces or veterans’ organization is not available; and
the Adjutant General determines that providing an honor guard will not harm:

sub-subparagraph.text: the readiness of the National Guard in the event of a State or federal emergency; or
the employment of a National Guard member.

paragraph.text: If an honor guard from the active armed forces is not available, the Adjutant General may request an honor guard from a veterans’ organization to attend the burial service of a deceased veteran.
The Adjutant General shall set reasonable compensation for honor guard members based on the availability of money in the budget.
Compensation may not exceed the expenses incurred to participate in the burial service of a deceased veteran plus the greater of:

subparagraph.text: 100% of 1 day’s pay as determined by the current Department of Defense pay scale; and
the minimum wage required under § 3-413 of the Labor and Employment Article.

subsection.text: The Adjutant General shall adopt regulations to carry out this section.

section.text: The Department may acquire by purchase or condemnation real property located in Baltimore County adjacent to the Martin State Airport that is necessary for the safe operation of the fighter squadron of the Maryland Air National Guard.

subsection.text: With the prior approval of the Board of Public Works, the Department may sell armories that are superfluous to the Department’s requirements.

paragraph.text: The county or municipal corporation in which the armory is located has the right of first refusal to purchase the armory.
If the county or municipal corporation declines to purchase the property, the Department shall sell the property at public sale for the highest cash price obtainable.

subsection.text: The proceeds of a sale shall be placed in the Annuity Bond Fund under § 8-132 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

section.text: The Military Department shall adopt regulations for exemption of a member of the organized militia from State jury service that would unreasonably interfere with the performance of the member’s military duties or affect adversely the readiness of the activity, command, or unit to which the member is assigned.

subsection.text: There is a Maryland Military Department Center for Military History.
The Maryland Military Department Center for Military History consists of the following components:

paragraph.text: the Maryland Museum of Military History; and
the Maryland Military Historical Research Center.

subsection.text: The Maryland Military Department Center for Military History shall be a component of the Maryland Military Department, and the Adjutant General of Maryland shall designate the Executive Director of the Maryland Military Department Center for Military History.

The Maryland Military Department shall provide staffing as determined available by the Adjutant General to the Maryland Museum of Military History and the Maryland Military Historical Research Center to include a director for each.
The Maryland Military Historical Society, Inc., a nonprofit organization, shall:

paragraph.text: serve as an advisory body to the Maryland Military Department Center for Military History, but may not engage in direct oversight of employees of the Maryland Military Department Center for Military History or its day–to–day operations;
be authorized to engage in fund–raising on behalf of the Center for Military History;

be authorized to provide volunteers to support activities of the Maryland Military Department Center for Military History without pay or compensation, except that the volunteers shall be eligible for benefits under workers’ compensation for injuries suffered in the course of volunteer work for the Maryland Military Department Center for Military History as if they were paid employees of the State; and

be authorized to use office space within facilities of the Maryland Military Department, independent of the space allotted to the Maryland Military Department Center for Military History on a space–available basis at the discretion of the Adjutant General.

subsection.text: The Maryland Museum of Military History shall:

paragraph.text: collect, preserve, interpret, and present significant artifacts and artwork relating to the history of the people, places, and events that represent all components and branches of each service of the United States military and the military heritage of the State; and
convey an awareness of the military service of Marylanders and how that service has helped preserve American freedoms through exhibits, educational programs, and outreach.

subsection.text: The Maryland Military Historical Research Center shall:

paragraph.text: collect, interpret, preserve, and present documents, photographs, electronic media, and other materials containing information or imagery relating to the history of the people, places, and events that represent all components and branches of each service of the United States military and the military heritage of the State;

educate the public regarding the military history of the State by providing bona fide researchers with access to collected materials and by providing historical imagery to support displays by the Maryland Museum of Military History; and
advise the Adjutant General and the Maryland Military Department generally on matters relating to the heraldry, honors, lineage, and history of units of the organized militia of the State.
The Maryland Military Department Center for Military History may assume title to abandoned property in its possession.
Property shall be considered abandoned if:

subparagraph.text: it has been in the possession of the Maryland Military Department Center for Military History for 7 years or more;
there are no known owners, or a reasonable attempt has been made to contact the owner without success, or the owner has been contacted but has refused to take possession of the property;

there are no known agreements to donate or lend the property, or there is a known agreement to lend the property for a finite period but the period of the loan has been exceeded by 7 or more years, or there is an agreement to lend the property for an indefinite period but the lender has been deceased for 7 or more years, or the property was lent by an organization that has been defunct for 7 or more years; and

a notice is posted in local newspapers for at least 2 weeks stating the intent to take title to the property if it is not claimed and the owner of the property does not contact the Maryland Museum of Military History within 1 week of the final publication of the notice.

subsection.text: The Adjutant General:

paragraph.text: is the head of the Department;
shall be appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate;
is subordinate only to the Governor in matters relating to the Department;
shall have a commissioned grade not above that of Lieutenant General; and
shall be a full–time employee of the Department in State active duty status.

subsection.text: At the time of appointment, the Adjutant General shall:

paragraph.text: have at least 2 years of commissioned field grade service in the National Guard;
have attained at least the rank of colonel; and
meet the requirements for federal recognition at the rank of Major General.

subsection.text: The Adjutant General is a member of the Governor’s Executive Council.

If the Adjutant General is ordered into the active military service of the United States, the Governor may designate an acting Adjutant General to exercise the duties of the Adjutant General during the period the Adjutant General is on active military service.

paragraph.text: The Adjutant General may appoint:

subparagraph.text: a chief of State operations;
an executive officer;
an administrative officer;
the directors of military installations, procurement, military support to civil authorities, State personnel, finance, and veterans affairs;
the site managers for military reservations; and
a grants administrator.

paragraph.text: The executive officer and directors appointed under paragraph (1) of this subsection serve at the pleasure of the Adjutant General.
The Adjutant General shall keep all records required to be kept and filed with the Adjutant General’s office.

On or before each October 15, the Adjutant General shall submit to the Governor a detailed statement of all the receipts and expenditures for military purposes during the year ending the previous September 30.

On request, the Adjutant General or the Adjutant General’s designee shall assist the spouse of a member of the military who resides in the State or is transferred to the State in finding employment in the State.
The assistance provided under paragraph (1) of this subsection may include providing:

subparagraph.text: the informational form developed by the State Department of Education under § 6–201.1 of the Education Article;
information relating to health occupations in the State that permit reciprocal licensure; and
information relating to business occupations in the State that permit reciprocal licensure.

paragraph.text: The Adjutant General is responsible for:

subparagraph.text: each armory that the State owns; and
each building or other property purchased, occupied, or leased by or on behalf of the State military forces.

paragraph.text: If the Adjutant General rejects an application to use an armory for nonmilitary purposes, the application is subject to review and approval by the Board of Public Works, the Adjutant General, and the commanding officer of the unit occupying that armory.
The Adjutant General may adopt regulations to enforce this subsection.

subsection.text: The Adjutant General is the custodian of battle flags and war records and is responsible for their proper care and preservation.
The Adjutant General may employ employees as required.
The Adjutant General shall carry out the Governor’s policies concerning matters specified in this title and Title 14, Subtitles 1, 2, and 4 of this article.
The seal of the Adjutant General’s office shall be delivered by the Adjutant General to the Adjutant General’s successor.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint two Assistant Adjutants General for the Maryland Army National Guard and two Assistant Adjutants General for the Maryland Air National Guard.
An Assistant Adjutant General serves at the pleasure of the Governor.
Unless selected for a military position requiring federal recognition as a Major General, an Assistant Adjutant General shall have a commissioned grade not above that of Brigadier General.

subsection.text: To be appointed as an Assistant Adjutant General an individual shall:

paragraph.text: have at least 1 year of commissioned field grade service in the National Guard; and
have attained at least the rank of colonel.

subsection.text: An Assistant Adjutant General shall perform the military duties that are assigned by the Governor or Adjutant General.

paragraph.text: One of the Assistant Adjutants General for the Maryland Army National Guard and one of the Assistant Adjutants General for the Maryland Air National Guard shall be full–time employees of the Department in State active duty status.
The other two Assistant Adjutants General shall be traditional drilling guard members.

section.text: The Adjutant General and the Assistant Adjutants General shall have a salary as stated in the annual budget.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint a Deputy Assistant Adjutant General for the Maryland Army National Guard.
The Deputy Assistant Adjutant General serves at the pleasure of the Adjutant General.

subsection.text: The Deputy Assistant Adjutant General for the Maryland Army National Guard shall:

paragraph.text: have a commissioned grade not above that of Brigadier General; and
perform the military duties assigned by the Governor or the Adjutant General.

subsection.text: Officers, warrant officers, and enlisted individuals who are full-time employees of the Department are in State active duty status.

paragraph.text: The Governor may appoint a chief of staff and aides.
The chief of staff and aides serve at the pleasure of the Governor.
The National Guard consists of:

subparagraph.text: the units of the organized militia allocated to the State by the United States Department of Defense that are supported wholly or partly by federal funds; and
individuals transferred with the approval of the Governor to the National Guard by federal authorities to complete a reserve service obligation imposed by federal law.

paragraph.text: The inactive National Guard consists of officers and enlisted individuals commissioned in, enlisted in, or transferred to the inactive National Guard.
An individual transferred to the National Guard is considered a member of the National Guard whether or not the individual executed the oath prescribed by § 13-206 of this title.

subsection.text: The National Guard and its units shall be organized as prescribed for the United States Army or United States Air Force, subject in time of peace to general exceptions that the Secretary of the Army or the Secretary of the Air Force authorize.

If the National Guard or any of its units are ordered into active military service of the United States by the President of the United States, the Governor may increase the military force and organize those units as the emergency requires.

A member of the National Guard has the same police power, authority, and status with respect to the enforcement of the law relating to criminal matters in the military area to which the member is assigned, as a law enforcement or peace officer has in the officer’s respective jurisdiction if:

paragraph.text: the Adjutant General designates the member as National Guard full-time support personnel under Title 32 of the United States Code;
the Department controls or has jurisdiction over the member; and
the member is acting as a National Guard member.

subsection.text: A member of the National Guard has the immunities and defenses available to a law enforcement or peace officer in a criminal proceeding or civil suit brought because of an act performed in the course of employment and duty under this section.
To maintain an appropriate organization and to assist in instruction and training, the President of the United States may:

paragraph.text: assign the National Guard to divisions, brigades, and other tactical units; and
detail officers from the National Guard or the United States Army or Air Force to command those units.

subsection.text: A commanding officer of a complete unit organized in the State may not be displaced under this section.
Except as otherwise authorized by law, the National Guard:

paragraph.text: is designated as a law enforcement agency for the sole purpose of receiving property and revenues; and

may receive property and revenues under 18 U.S.C. § 981(e)(2), 19 U.S.C. § 1616a(c)(1)(B)(ii), and 21 U.S.C. §§ 881(e)(1)(A) and (e)(3) from those federal units that are supported by National Guard members in the Counter Drug Program.
Any property or revenues received by the National Guard under this section shall be used to supplement the resources allocated to the Counter Drug Program.

The use of the property and revenues shall conform to the guidelines of the United States Department of Justice, the United States Department of Defense, and the United States Department of the Treasury.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Institution” means:

subparagraph.text: any campus of the University System of Maryland, any community college established under Title 16 of the Education Article, Morgan State University, or St. Mary’s College;
any private institution of higher education that grants a member a tuition waiver of at least 50%;
any public postsecondary vocational–technical or trade school; or
any private postsecondary vocational–technical or trade school that grants a member a tuition waiver of at least 50%.

paragraph.text: “Member” means an individual who:

subparagraph.text: is regularly enlisted in the National Guard; or
holds a commission in the National Guard as:

sub-subparagraph.text: an officer in the grade of major or below; or
a warrant officer.

subparagraph.text: “Tuition” means the basic instructional charge for undergraduate, graduate, professional, vocational–technical, and trade school credit courses and related fees at an institution.
“Tuition” does not include charges for self–supporting programs.

paragraph.text: To the extent that funds are provided in the State budget, the Department may provide assistance equal to 50% of the cost of in–State tuition for any regularly scheduled undergraduate credit course, graduate credit course, professional credit course, vocational–technical course, or trade course for any active member attending an institution who is certified as eligible by the Adjutant General.

A member who receives assistance under paragraph (1) of this subsection for an undergraduate credit, vocational–technical, or trade course shall remain an active member for at least 2 years following the completion of the course.

A member who receives assistance under paragraph (1) of this subsection for a graduate or professional credit course shall remain an active member for at least 4 years following the completion of the course.
The Adjutant General may not certify a member as eligible unless the member is:

subparagraph.text: enlisted and has at least 24 months remaining to serve on the current enlistment of the member; or
an officer or warrant officer and agrees in writing to serve for a minimum of 24 months.

paragraph.text: The 24–month requirement runs from the first day of classes for the semester.

subsection.text: If a recipient of tuition assistance under this section is discharged from the National Guard for a reason designated by the Adjutant General, the assistance terminates and the member shall reimburse the Department the amount of tuition assistance received for that semester within 30 days of discharge.
This section:

paragraph.text: applies when the National Guard is ordered out for State active duty or training by the Governor or by the Governor’s authority; and
does not apply to the National Guard when ordered to duty incident to an order into the active military service of the United States.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (d) of this section:

paragraph.text: an officer, warrant officer, and enlisted individual shall receive the same pay, including longevity pay, subsistence, per diem, and allowances, as an officer, warrant officer, and enlisted individual of like grade and length of service in the United States Army or Air Force; and
an individual ordered to active duty other than for training shall be paid a daily rate of at least 12 times the hourly federal minimum wage in effect at the time of active duty.

subsection.text: An enlisted individual who meets the qualifications that the Governor sets in small arms practice or for proficiency in the various duties of the branch or arm to which the individual belongs shall receive the following increase in pay of the individual’s grade for 1 year beginning on the first January 1 after qualification:

paragraph.text: experts – 20%;
sharpshooters, gunners, drivers, and medical, first class – 15%; and
marksmen, gunners, drivers, and medical, second class – 10%.

subsection.text: On the recommendation of the Adjutant General, the Governor may reduce the rates of pay, including longevity pay and qualification pay under subsections (b) and (c) of this section.

section.text: A commissioned officer of the National Guard shall take the following oath of office:

“I, ..............., do solemnly swear that I will support and defend the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Maryland, against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I will obey the orders of the President of the United States and of the Governor of the State of Maryland; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion, and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties of the office of ................... in the National Guard of the United States and of the State of Maryland upon which I am about to enter, so help me God.”
An officer of the National Guard shall take rank from the date that the officer was commissioned and in the manner the United States Department of Defense provides by regulation.

subsection.text: Any individual who is ordered into active duty for the National Guard in response to the foreign terrorist attacks in the United States on September 11, 2001, shall receive a service bar in recognition of this service.
The service bar shall depict the State flag and “9–11”.

paragraph.text: There is established in the State a Maryland Defense Force within the Military Department.
The Governor is the commander–in–chief of the Maryland Defense Force.
The Maryland Defense Force is under the operational control of the Adjutant General.
There is a commanding general of the Maryland Defense Force who is appointed by the Adjutant General and serves as such at the pleasure of the Adjutant General.

subsection.text: The Maryland Defense Force is a component of the organized militia of the State in addition to and separate from the National Guard.

The Maryland Defense Force shall have the primary mission of providing competent and supplemental professional, technical, and military support to the Maryland Army National Guard, the Maryland Air National Guard, and the Maryland Emergency Management Agency. The Maryland Defense Force shall also have other duties and missions as it may be assigned from time to time by competent authority.

paragraph.text: The Governor may adopt regulations to carry out this title governing the enlistment, organization, administration, equipment, maintenance, training, and discipline of the Maryland Defense Force.
The Governor may prescribe a uniform for the Maryland Defense Force.

subsection.text: As is practicable and desirable, regulations adopted under this section shall conform to applicable law and regulations that govern the National Guard, except those laws and regulations that apply to the National Guard when acting solely under Title 10 of the United States Code.

paragraph.text: The regulations shall prohibit the Maryland Defense Force or a member of the Maryland Defense Force from accepting gifts, donations, gratuities, or anything of value from a person in exchange for specific and isolated services rendered by the Maryland Defense Force.

This provision may not be interpreted otherwise to prohibit gifts, bequests, and the like from any individual or organization to the Maryland Defense Force or any foundation or the like established to support its activities.

subsection.text: The Maryland Defense Force consists of:

paragraph.text: commissioned or assigned officers; and
qualified individuals who volunteer to serve and are commissioned, appointed, or enlisted in the Maryland Defense Force.

subsection.text: An individual may not be commissioned or enlisted in the Maryland Defense Force if the individual:

paragraph.text: is not a citizen of the United States;

has been dismissed from or received a bad conduct discharge or a dishonorable discharge, or any discharge other than under honorable conditions, from a military or naval organization of this State or of another state, or from any of the United States armed forces or its auxiliaries, or has been convicted of an offense under the laws of the United States or of any state punishable by imprisonment for more than 1 year, no matter what punishment was actually imposed; or
does not meet the qualifications for commissioning, appointment, or enlistment specified in regulations governing the Maryland Defense Force.

subsection.text: A civil organization, society, club, post, order, fraternity, association, brotherhood, body, union, league, or other combination of persons or civil groups may not enlist in the Maryland Defense Force as an organization or unit.

paragraph.text: All members of the Maryland Defense Force serve on a voluntary basis and without pay, unless under orders, approved by the Adjutant General, specifying that their service is with pay.
If an order approved by the Adjutant General specifies that the service of a member of the Maryland Defense Force is with pay, the member may be compensated in accordance with § 13–406 of this title.

subsection.text: An officer or warrant officer commissioned or appointed in the Maryland Defense Force shall take the oath prescribed in § 13–509 of this subtitle.

An individual who enlists in the Maryland Defense Force shall take an oath substantially in the form required for enlisted personnel of the National Guard, substituting “Maryland Defense Force” where necessary in the oath.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the enlistment period in the Maryland Defense Force is 2 years and may be renewed.

In the case that a state of war exists between the United States and any other nation, or that there is a federal or State declaration of emergency presently in force in the State, all enlistments shall continue until 3 months after said state of war or emergency ends, unless the enlisted individual is discharged sooner by proper authority.

subsection.text: The Governor may accept the resignation of an officer or grant a discharge to an enlisted individual at any time.
The Governor may requisition any arms and equipment from the Secretary of the Army that are in the possession of and can be spared by the Department of the Army for use by the Maryland Defense Force.
The Governor may allow the Maryland Defense Force to use the facilities and equipment of a State armory or other available State premises and property.
A school authority may allow the Maryland Defense Force to use a school building or school grounds.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, the Maryland Defense Force may not be required to serve outside the State.

This section does not apply to any instance in which the Maryland Defense Force as part of the organized militia of the State is ordered into service of the United States by the President pursuant to the Constitution and laws of the United States.

On request of the governor of another state, the Governor of this State may order the Maryland Defense Force to serve outside the State to assist the military or other public safety forces of the requesting state.
The Governor of this State may recall the Maryland Defense Force from the other state.

subsection.text: If fresh pursuit is authorized by law of another state, any organization, unit, or detachment of the Maryland Defense Force, on the order of the commanding officer of the organization, unit, or detachment, may continue in fresh pursuit of insurrectionists, saboteurs, or enemies outside of this State into the other state until:

paragraph.text: the insurrectionists, saboteurs, or enemies are apprehended; or
the military or law enforcement forces of the other state or forces of the United States have had a reasonable opportunity to pursue or apprehend the insurrectionists, saboteurs, or enemies.
An organization, unit, or detachment of the Maryland Defense Force shall surrender without unnecessary delay an individual apprehended in another state to the military or law enforcement force of:

subparagraph.text: the state of apprehension; or
the United States.
